goal: Successfully perform dormant seeding for optimal grass growth in Ohio.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
I have a quick question about dormant seeding. Should I wait until next month to apply the seeds for optimal results, and is it necessary to water the area after seeding? I can time it on a day I know it's going to rain. 
I checked soil temp and it's currently 37F, with a 5-day average of 50F. I understand that spring seeding is generally preferred, but I’m interested in trying dormant seeding this year.
Thank you very much for your help!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: I am concerned about your timing. See the FactShhet below. Our winters are so variable with warm spells followed by extreme cold, at this point you might be better off waiting as described by the second FactSheet specific to Ohio. The optimal time for all grass seating is in September. Unless you have extensive bare spots or are willing to vigilantly water this coming summer. You might consider waiting until next early fall. https://extension.umn.edu/lawn-care/dormant-seeding   Winters with extended warm periods followed by extremely cold periods can negatively affect spring germination of dormant seeded lawns. Dormant seeding works best when you want to reseed bare soil areas or help thicken up thin lawns. It is not as effective where lawns are thick and dense because good seed-to-soil contact is necessary for the grass seeds to germinate and grow next spring. The time to dormant seed is important. If done too early, some seed will germinate late in the season and those immature seedlings often won’t survive the winter. Put down your seed while the ground is not frozen, but is still cold enough so germination of the grass seed will not occur until next spring. Usually, this is from late October to mid-November depending on your location.  FactSheet 2 with information specific to Ohio in 2024: https://buckeyeturf.osu.edu/news/seed-establishment-fall  An excerpt: Dormant Seeding as an Alternative If the team decides it's too late for even fast-germinating species, dormant seeding offers another option. Dormant seeding involves applying seed that will not germinate until conditions improve in spring. Typically done in late winter (February-March), dormant seeding could also occur in late fall or early winter, provided a mulch or cover protects the seed from washing away. The aim is to prevent soil erosion over winter (Figure 4) and promote early germination in spring 2025, giving turf a head start as soon as conditions allow.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you very much for the detailed guidance! I really appreciate it. Just to clarify, it sounds like you’re suggesting that dormant seeding should be done later in the winter, around February-March, as an alternative to mid-November seeding. This timing would allow the seeds to stay dormant until early spring, when they could start germinating with the warming soil. Since I live by myself, I'm hoping to do this with minimal effort, letting natural winter processes help settle the seeds into the soil. Will dormant seeding during late winter allow the earth's natural freeze-thaw cycle to work the seeds in effectively enough for early spring growth? When I do this in February, I don't need to worry about watering do I? Thank you again for your help! Layla     From: ask=<personal data hidden> on behalf of Ask Extension  Sent: Wednesday, November 13, 2024 8:59 PM To: Layla Adams  Subject: Re: Dormant Seeding Timing and Watering Advice (#0159723)

missing: User's specific lawn condition (e.g., bare spots, thin lawn, or dense lawn)

expected_output: Can you describe the current condition of your lawn? For example, are there extensive bare spots, is it thin, or is it already dense? This will help determine the effectiveness of dormant seeding in your case.
title: Dormant Seeding Timing and Watering Advice

goal: Determine the best method and timing for treating a Spring Snow Crabapple tree to prevent or manage fire blight.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: When should my Spring Snow Crabapple be treated with antibiotic injections in the Spring?  Should it be done before bud break or when the buds first appear?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello! Fire blight can be difficult to control, but its severity also varies strongly with spring weather conditions (with cooler, wetter conditions typically favoring extensive infections).   Antibiotics are used as a preventative measure when the tree is flowering, applied every three to four days as a spray.  If the tree has symptoms of fire blight, they are not recommended--they don't work well to control active infections in branches and overuse in this situation can lead to antibiotic resistance of both the pathogen and other environmental bacteria.  Some antibiotic products are not labeled for ornamental trees or non-orchard settings and so could not be used in a home landscape in any case.  The product label will specify use requirements. If your tree was impacted by fire blight this past year, pruning out visible cankers over the winter at least 18" below the visible canker margin and spraying copper-based fungicides/disinfestants in the spring both before and during bud-break can help limit the spread of the disease and are both more accessible and more effective options for home landscapes.  Several copper-sulfate and copper-ammonium products are labeled for this use; be sure to read an follow all label directions for mixing and application--the label is the law. A tree-care professional could also apply growth regulators to your apple tree, which can harden twigs and make them less susceptible to infections.  Minimizing over-watering and excess nitrogen fertilizer will also help to make the tree more resistant to bacterial growth. I hope this is helpful. Cordially, John

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: The Arborist we use has recommended antibiotic injections in the Spring for the Spring Snow Crabapple tree,  You indicated its use as a spray.  Is a spray advised rather than injections?  Thanks.On Nov 13, 2024, at 8:57 AM, Ask Extension wrote:

known.concern: fire blight
known.current recommendation: antibiotic injections in the Spring by an arborist
known.user's question: whether sprays are advised over injections

missing: Has the tree shown symptoms of fire blight in the past?
What is the user's preference or ability to apply treatments themselves?

expected_output: Has your Spring Snow Crabapple shown symptoms of fire blight in the past, or is this a preventative measure?
title: Treating fire blight with antibiotic injections

goal: Reduce phosphorus and potassium levels in the soil and establish a suitable cover crop for nitrogen fixation and soil improvement.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Just had a soil test done everything looked good except two things that I 
don't remember happening in last years soil test the Phosphorous level came out at 41.3 ppm  normal levels.    8.0--20.0, potassium 109.84 normal levels 38.0-80.0  can I plant a. Nitrogen fixing legume to bring the P & K levels back to a reasonable number and what legume would you plant at this time of the year. The only other numbers that where off where nitrogen very low and sulfur a little bit low. To be expected

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: A legume cover crop will not particularly reduce P or K, beyond what the crop takes up. It's rainfall that reduces these.   I'd say it's late to plant any cover crop - seed generally requires warmth to germinate.  Still if you're determined, among the legumes, right now I'd try crimson clover (an annual - freely self-seeding) or hairy vetch ( another free self seeder.)   Among the grasses, I'd plant rye or oats - the latter will cold kill, the former will hang on though out the winter. Grasses form dense root mats, which may be harder to work into the soil. Of course, I'm in the no-till crowd. If you are not, it should be not too much trouble.  Among the forbs, I'd try radish or beet - or arugula.   Whatever you sow at this time of year, sow PLENTY of seed, as the germination rates will be reduced.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Linda, what you are saying in a nut shell is strip off the vegetation and  let the rain reduce the P & K. Unfortunately  I have been appointed resident gardener at this Assisted Living Facility by default because I am the only resident that can make it to the raised bed boxes in the cavernous backyard on a consistent basis This growing season we got a grant to construct new growing beds. The group is called growing Gardens, unique name. I am sure the person I am working with in that group is going to want to plant (Green manure) a cover crop that we can turn under if and when the soil dries in the spring.  I have read that Alfalfa fixes the greatest amount of Nitrogen  followed by the plants in the clover family. Which you suggested. The new grow  boxes are a pattern growing gardens have perfected overthe years. The old lumber which was badly rotted was carried away and new 4 x 8 raised beds where constructed by high-school kids under the supervision of a master carpenter. On Wed, Nov 13, 2024, 9:44 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: David w Madison -   I didn't express myself very well. I don't mean that you should strip off any vegetation at this time of year - far from it. What I mean is that 1) the rainfall (over time) will reduce the P and K levels, and that 2) growing a crop and harvesting the crop is another means by which P and K are removed from the soil.  It's very nice that you were able to engage the local high school students to rebuild your beds.   It may well be that alfalfa is the most efficient legume at fixing nitrogen, but alfalfa is a perennial crop, with roots that can go to 12 feet - I would not recommend it for a raised bed. Further, this time of year is not right for planting alfalfa. It would be a waste of seed and you could expect very low germination. And it would be very difficult to turn under.  I continue to recommend the legumes stated yesterday. Either would be far easier to turn under than alfalfa. dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: I agree that aphids can be difficult to get after on cherries especially if you wait till you see a lot of them. We scout ahead and when we see the first ones of the season we go after them right away.  As for what is wrong with your trees we will need more information and/or images showing us what the whole tree and area looks like. A few purple leaves does not tell us much about what might be wrong.  Cherries and apricots are stone fruit and get very similar problems so one could spread to the other. A little more info and maybe we can help. In the mean time, have a look at this publication:  For home orchardists we have this resource for IPM of these pests: https://extension.oregonstate.edu/sites/default/files/documents/ec631.pdf

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: If I use triple fertile to get them and k needed for my grass,  it grows fast but doesn't help the root growth which is very important. So with the triple fertilizer what can I use for better root growth?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: I'm sorry but your question isn't very clear to me.  It sounds like you want to increase root growth while using triple fertilizer (which contains phosphorous).  Beginning January 1, 2012, phosphorus fertilizer applications are restricted on residential lawns in Michigan unless a soil test indicates the need for phosphorous.  More info in the article in the attached link:  State of MI Phosphorous Restriction for Lawns  The MSU soil test will give you data on the fertility of your soil (phosphorous level, potassium level, magnesium level, calcium level, CEC, soil type, lime index, pH and organic matter%). Knowing the type and fertility of your soil is the starting point to establishing & maintaining a strong turf that can resist diseases, weeds, moss and insects/grubs, look great and at an optimal cost. More info here: Don't Guess-Soil Test-MSU and MSU Home Soil Test-self mailer It provides recommendations on fertilization and pH changes if needed.  Phosphorous (P) is important for root development and flowering.  Too much phosphorous is detrimental to lakes and streams.  Potassium (K) promotes natural plant resistance to disease, drought, cold and heat damage. Here is part of my confusion-you want better root growth (from phosphorous) but you want to add more potassium (K) which doesn't affect root growth. Another way to increase root growth is to mow higher.  Read the articles in the attached links:  Mowing Lawn Turf (E0013TURF) - MSU Why Mow High-MSU Root depth varies naturally between spring (deeper), summer (shallower) and fall  (deeper).  Do not fertilize too early in the spring as the nitrogen will force top growth at the expense of root growth. Bottom line....  Do a soil test (if you haven't done one in the past 2 years), if the results indicate a need for phosphorous continue using your triple fertilizer and follow the test report fertilizing recommendations.  If P is not needed, stop using the triple.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: i am sorry my question was not clear. i did do a soil test and it suggested i use the triple fertilizer. by using that fertilizer it means my grass root growth will be more shallow. if I am understanding my reply if I use the triple fertilizer a little later in the spring it may not affect the root growth. sorry it has always been my understanding that deep root growth makes for a healthier lawn On Tue, Nov 5, 2024 at 10:05 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

known.user_concern: Triple fertilizer promotes fast growth but may not support root growth.
known.fertilizer: Triple fertilizer is recommended by a soil test.
known.user_action: User has conducted a soil test.

missing: Timing of current fertilizer application.

expected_output: When do you typically apply the triple fertilizer to your lawn?
title: Soil test ( lawns)

goal: Effectively manage and mitigate the damage caused by gophers, moles, and voles in pastures to ensure the safety of livestock and guardian dogs.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: We’re having a terrible problems with holes from gophers, moles and voles in our pastures. The guardian dogs then dig bigger holes hunting them. These are a serious risk for our herding and guardian dogs as well as our sheep. We are trapping somewhat successfully. Do you have recommendations for how to deal with the holes without working up the fields? Thank you!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Let's first make sure you have all 3 species in the pasture. Traps, toxicants, and potential monitoring/management can be very different for each of those. Could you please upload photos of undisturbed (i.e., pre-dog and pre-sheep interactions) sign that you're seeing? If there are above-ground mounds of dirt, it would really help (alot!) to get a photo of a fresh, pre-rained-on mound, too - Which, I realize, could be nearly impossible today, but perhaps tomorrow if we get a break in the precip?

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi-I can get photos if needed but we have trapped gophers and moles and our English shepherds catch voles all the time. The question was more how to deal with the holes they’ve caused that are so dangerous. We aren’t in a position to work up the pastures and reseed. What would you recommend? Thank you!CarlaOn Nov 4, 2024, at 9:29 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: I think perhaps we need more input from a pastures/forage agronomist. My expertise is wildlife ecology, so I advise on things like replanting to diminish food and thus carrying capacity for that particular species of animal, but it sounds like 1)trapping is not affordable/effective at the scale you're attempting to do so 2)the dogs are creating an additional hazard to the livestock and 3) there's no way to rebuild or replant the field. I have no expertise on how to fill/resurface your pasture short of using equipment to do so, and it sounds like if you were to passive/broadcast for some other plant species that would support fewer of whichever small mammal is making the holes of greatest damage (or interest to the digging dogs), that I wouldn't know what to have you plant that would be safe and sufficiently supportive of your sheep. As to simply leveling if you're talking (still unsure from what's provided) knocking down mounds from gophers or moles, perhaps just a manure drag behind an ATV? Would that work?

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I’ve attached a few photos. We caught another gopher tonight. In the past the voles have been terrible but they aren’t so bad this year. Rather, it’s the gophers that are the worst and moles 2nd. It’s pretty clear we will have to haul dirt to fill the holes the dogs have dug, but the places where there are just a ton of holes are more difficult. We have a harrow and we can turn it around to serve as a drag, but lots of these holes are deep—leg breakers for stock and dogs. Maybe multiple harrow passes followed by a drag? I was hoping someone at extension might have some suggestions beyond what we’re thinking of. Please look your pastures/forage specialist in if you think they might be of help.It was getting dark when I was taking photos so didn’t have a chance to get to the place where the moles have been working. And, I’m not sure how well you can see the extent of the problem from the photos, but perhaps they’ll give you an idea. If you have suggestions for things that would be palatable/good forage for sheep that gophers in particular don’t like, and that we could overseed, we’d appreciate the suggestions. Thank you!CarlaOn Nov 4, 2024, at 3:03 PM, Ask Extension wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: I would contact one or more of the pasture specialists linked to this page https://extension.oregonstate.edu/crop-production/pastures-forages/revitalizing-your-pastures-primer-overseeding-pastures-western about best choices for overseeding, etc. From your photos, I see alot of vole activity, including vole burrows up through the mounds of either gopher or mole. There are registered, restricted-use products (primarily ZincPhosphide) that are labeled for in-burrow (i.e., hand-baiting) for both voles and gophers. Products such as zinc phosphide, strychnine, etc., are not species-specific -- So if you decided to treat the pasture prior to doing overseeding, you'd really want to be careful/thoughtful about allowing your other animals and stock access to prospective contact (inhalation or ingestion) of the bait or ingestion of animals containing the bait. This is part of why these products are restricted access & use, which means you either have to have a pesticide applicator license (many farm owner-operators do), or need to contract with somebody who is licensed and thus able to purchase and apply those products. One subgroup of qualified applicators would be those who are also trained and licensed as Wildlife Control Operators, so you might contact one or more and request a free estimate: https://www.dfw.state.or.us/wildlife/license_permits_apps/wildlife_control_operator_contacts.asp

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you. We are unwilling to risk poisons given our dogs and stock. On Nov 5, 2024, at 11:45 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

goal: Identify the origin of the brownish, fruit-fly-sized objects on the user's bathroom wall.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Are the oval brownish fruit-fly sized things on my bathroom wall from a fruit fly?  Leavings or alive?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: If you intended to attach photos to your inquiry, unfortunately we did not receive them. You're welcome to try again, but images will need to be very clear and well-lit (and ideally include a ruler for scale) so we can try to ID something that small.  Fruit flies, and any other type of fly, need a source of moisture for their larvae to live in. It doesn't need to be open water, like tiny puddles that can harbor mosquito larvae, but it does need to be something damp, like residue lining a drain (for drain flies), organic matter below a house (for phorid flies), or fermenting fruits (for fruit flies), as several examples. Excrement from fruit flies would probably not be as noticeable as what you're describing, but if you're not seeing any adult flies of any type, than it's probably due to some other cause.  Miri

dialog_context.text: Thanks, Miri!I do have some fruit flies.  I've trapped and smacked some and try to keep food & dirty dishes where they can't get at them.  I see none or just one per day now.  I don't think I could see excrement and I can't usefully photograph what I can see because it's so little. It's fruit-fly size and motionless on the bathroom wall.  Does the maggot leave something behind when it becomes a fly?  Does the immediately post-maggot fly sit still somewhere to dry and get able to fly?Thanks again Dorita On Nov 4, 2024, at 10:28 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

goal: Successfully grow healthy potatoes from seed in containers.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I grew potatoes from seed for the first time this year. Harvested last week before any big frosts, I was surprised that most of them are soft and wrinkled. I soaked them overnight in a bucket of water, thinking they might be de-hydrated, but there was no improvement. What did I do wrong? Are they edible?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Brigitte,  Following harvest, potatoes should be stored in a humid, but cool (60 degrees), environment to allow them to "cure" for 10-14 days. This allows the skin to thicken and can also allow bruises or small cuts to heal. Then you can move the potatoes to a fridge or other cool place (about 40 degrees) that is well-ventilated. Using perforated bags (like mesh or plastic) with holes is a good choice.  Unfortunately, your potatoes will not store long-term and are likely to spoil. You can try eating them, but they probably won't taste great. Soaking them in water will not rehydrate them.  CSU Extension does have a fact sheet on growing potatoes.  From that publication: After harvest, the potatoes should be stored in a dark place with high humidity at 50 to 60F for about two weeks to cure, or set the skin. This can occur in a cooler part of the house, such as a utility room with a portable humidifier. The potatoes are then ready for long term storage in the dark at 40F, which prevents the potatoes from sprouting or shriveling due to moisture loss. The tubers should not be kept in sealed containers, but should be stored in burlap bags or slotted bins conducive to airflow. If they will be eaten within a week, potatoes can be stored at room temperature.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: My question was why did they come out of the ground looking like that in the first place? A disease?BrigitteSent from my iPhone On Nov 4, 2024, at 10:45 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi again,  It probably stems to something cultural during the growing process - from drought, heat, cold, too much moisture, or a combination of things. It could be also disease.  If you cut back on watering late in the season, but still had green vines, then it's likely this resulted in water loss (potatoes are mostly water) to the tubers.  It's hard to say without knowing more about how they were grown and maintained during the season.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your reply. I grew these potatoes in a large approx. 2 ft high black bin on top of landscaping cloth, in order to avoid worms which burrowed through potatoes I grew in the ground during past years. I watered consistently, but maybe not enough for them to be comfortable and healthy. I will chalk that experiment off as a failure. Sigh.Brigitte DempseyOn Nov 4, 2024, at 1:50 PM, Ask Extension wrote:

known.location: 2 ft high black bin on top of landscaping cloth
known.previous experience: issues with worms in ground-grown potatoes

goal: Identify the cause of dieback on the user's heartnut tree and provide a solution.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Hey, I'm wondering what caused dieback on one of our heartnuts.

We planted two heartnuts (Juglans ailantifolia) in 2009.  In early October this year (2024), one of them looked thirsty (somewhat wilty-looking leaves), so I set a sprinkler under it for several hours, on the south side, then on the north.  A week later (Oct 14), I noticed the top half had lost all of its leaves, and the bark had this grid-pattern of depressions and what look like (but aren't really) vertical ridges.  My first thought was some kind of fungal or bacterial disease affecting the vascular system.  It looks so different from sapsucker holes on other trees around here (cherries, oaks, etc), but maybe it's from a sapsucker, and just got to be too much? What do you know?  Thanks!

goal: Improve soil conditions for better gardening results, specifically addressing issues with low nitrogen, high phosphorus, and heavy clay soil.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Hello! I've been gardening for 15 years and am stumped on how to move forward in regards to 3 issues I'm having (low nitrogen, high phosphorus, and amending heavy clay soil). I appreciate your help! 

I put in a new 1300 sq ft in-ground garden in May 2023 and did a soil test on 11/14/2023 and again on 10/28/2024 (see attached photos for the full reports). Since last year, I've had a large spike in phosphorus, which is now high. I added composted cow manure in May 2023 and again in April 2024, however, the composted cow manure that I obtained in 2024 contained quite a few animal bones (ew). Perhaps, that's where the high phosphorus came from? 

I'm cleaning up my garden and was preparing to add more compost this fall to replenish my garden (using the original composted cow manure with no animal bones), but now I'm stumped on a few things:
1) Is the phosphorus high enough to where I should avoid adding compost this year? I know even bone-free compost contains a decent amount of phosphorus. I'm pleased to see that nearly all of my soil nutrients have increased from 2023, so perhaps skipping this year would be okay (minus the nitrogen - more on that in a minute)?
2) If it's best for me to avoid adding compost, I feel like I still need to add something to continue my efforts to lighten up my heavy clay soil. I've read that adding sand isn't the best. Is there something else I could use? I use no-till methods and utilize a broadfork each spring to try to do some deep aerating and mulch throughout the growing season to encourage worm activity. I'm not afraid of trying expensive or labor-intensive ideas, so I'm open to anything you think might work :) 
3) Lastly, I'm stumped on my very low nitrogen levels, which are even lower than they were before. I added 24 lbs of blood meal (12-0-0) in April 2024. Should I add even more, or am I missing something here?

I so appreciate your expertise!! I'm pretty stumped on what to do going forward. Thanks so much.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thanks for your question.  It has been assigned to me.  In formulating an answer, I need a bit more information from you: 1).  You indicated that you have a soil texture largely consisting of clay.  Soil texture is not indicated on either of the two soil reports.  Is your statement that you have a clay soil texture solely based upon your own observations and working with the soil? 2).  You indicated that you did a soil test on 10/28/24.  You submitted your question on 10/29/24. If you took a soil sample on 10/28/24, I don't understand how you could have received soil test results back so quickly. Perhaps you took a soil sample prior to 10/28/24 but received the results on 10/28/24?  Please clarify. 3).  Where did you have these soil tests performed and from whom did you get the results? Looking forward to you getting back to us.  Many thanks.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Good morning and thank you for your help! Here’s my response to your questions:1) Correct. I haven’t had my soil texture tested, but it’s definitely clay based on my observations and working with the soil. It’s slimy and feels like pottery clay when wet and turns to a fine dust/powder when dry (I get puffs around my feet when walking). 2) Oh, yes! Sorry about that, I just read the date off of the soil test report. I believe 10/28/24 was the day they analyzed the sample and I collected it on 10/18/24. 3) I used a test kit from MySoil (https://www.mysoiltesting.com/) that I mailed to them for analysis. Are you able to open the attachments to see the reports?Thank you! Katie Krejci<personal data hidden>  On Oct 30, 2024, at 6:43 AM, Ask Extension wrote:

known.soil issues: low nitrogen, high phosphorus, heavy clay soil
known.recent actions: added composted cow manure in May 2023 and April 2024, added 24 lbs of blood meal in April 2024
known.soil test results: attached photos of reports from 11/14/2023 and 10/28/2024
known.user's observation: soil is clay based on texture when wet and dry

goal: Successfully store dahlia and canna bulbs over the winter to replant in the spring.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
We have numerous canna bulbs growing, some planted in the ground and some in pots.  The pots have already come inside for the winter.  My question relates to the suggested method for storing the bulbs over the winter.  The bulbs I attempted to save from last fall dried up and died and I had to discard them all.  What can I do to preserve the bulbs over the winter so that they can be planted again in the spring?  

When the foliage stops producing in the pots we brought in, what should I do with those bulbs? Leave them in the pots or remove them and store them somewhere else?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: In the fall, dig up the rhizomes, cut the stems back to 2 to 3 inches, and let them dry. Leave them in a box in a cool part of the house where they will not freeze, such as a basement where the temperatures range between 40 to 50 degrees. Finding that place where the temperature is between 40 and 50 can be a challenge. Most basements are warmer than that and most garages are colder than that. Here is the link to the tip sheet on cannas:  https://extension.umn.edu/flowers/calla-and-canna-lilies Paul -Master Gardener volunteer

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: What about dahlias? goal: Determine the cause of leaf loss on the oak tree and ensure its recovery.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Tree was planted by MC over a year ago. Recently, all the top leaves disappeared.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: If the oak's leader just lost its leaves early, then it might be fine; sometimes portions of a canopy will defoliate in autumn earlier than others. Otherwise, it might be weakened or dead/dying, in which case it would need to be pruned off. That might be hard to determine, though, until sometime next spring when it would be leafing back out again. What would have caused such dieback is hard to determine, but it might have been drought stress if the tree wasn't being regularly monitored for watering needs, given the drought this summer (and part of last year as well). We presume the mulch ring and trunk wrap has prevented any lawn equipment from hitting the bark, since that can cause serious or fatal injuries to trees, but you can look for indications of trunk damage right around the soil/mulch level in case it hasn't been in place since the planting took place.  While nothing can be done to reverse any existing damage or dieback in the canopy, you can keep monitoring it for watering needs as it goes dormant, since leaf buds lying in wait for next year are relying on enough soil moisture to survive the winter, and roots can still be stressed or lost due to drought even if the canopy is bare for winter. Trees with canopy damage can replace lost growth eventually, though it might take a few years for a new leader to emerge from the regrowth.  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Miri, Thanks for your response. I did water the tree regularly throughout the drought. The rest of the tree looks great. There is no damage to the trunk. This all just happened in the last few weeks. First just the very top leaves, then a week later, more of the top fell off. I will continue to water it and hope for the best next season. ArleneOn Mon, Oct 28, 2024 at 11:36 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Russell, We are waiting on MSU Extension to publish a drafted home fruit spray guide, but in the meantime I like to suggest this guide from New Hampshire: https://extension.unh.edu/sites/default/files/migrated_unmanaged_files/Resource005256_Rep7402.pdf  A general product like Bonide's fruit spray has limited ability to control every issue, especially on a difficult to manage cultivar like Honeycrisp. There are home spray products that have more specific and effective control than the general product you have been using. Just as important is timing your sprays effectively. You can use a tool like Enviroweather https://enviroweather.msu.edu/ to monitor conditions for specific pests and disease in your area based on weather conditions in addition to following the articles published in-season by our extension staff (for you the Northwest MI reports will be best) https://www.canr.msu.edu/fruit/  If you haven't done a soil test recently you should have one done, which would come with recommendations for fertilization. https://homesoiltest.msu.edu/get-started  Your practice of keeping the orchard free from diseased fruit is one you should continue.

goal: Find a resilient grass seed suitable for a lawn in a flood-prone, brackish water area.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Good Day

I live in a flood zone area where my lawn from time to time is flooded by tidal water. I live where the water is brackish, up the bay on the Gunpowder river. 

The area is adjacent to phragmites.

My entire lawn can flood but the area I have trouble with is newly seeded areas. 

This past spring I brought in soil, seeded and covered and the lawn took quite well, all summer long. But recently and with the new areas looking good and established,  we had a series of high tides and the seeded areas died again. The areas that died off had been established since early spring. This all unraveled a few weeks back.

Is there a tuff or resilient seed worth trying? 

Bill 

Thanks for your help.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: How lovely to live on the water! But how frustrating it must be to put in all that effort to have it flood out and die. Unfortunately, due to climate change, it is more likely than ever that your landscape will continue to flood periodically. The way to best deal with that is to readjust what you think of as typical 'lawn', and plant salt-tolerant species which can survive periodic inundation, which will surely happen again. These species of grass (or grass-like rushes) have some salt tolerance. Most will require full sun to thrive, and salt levels aside, some will also need better drainage than others. Those with the best salt tolerance (moderate **, high ***) are noted. Broomsedge (Andropogon virginicus)**Soft Rush (Juncus effusus)**Black Needlerush (Juncus roemerianus)***Wool Rush (Scirpus cyperinus)Smooth Cordgrass (Spartina alternifolia)***Saltmeadow Hay (Spartina patens)***Big Cordgrass (Spartina cynosuroides)***Giant Bulrush (Schoenoplectus validus)**Saltmarsh Rush (Juncus gerardii)***Bitter Beachgrass/Panicgrass (Panicum amarum)***Dunegrass (Ammophila brevilgulata)***Bushy Bluestem (Andropogon glomeratus)**Seashore Saltgrass (Distichlis spicata)***Canada Rush (Juncus canadensis) Most are not 'typical' turf grass lawn, but can be beautiful. We are always suggesting that people re-imagine how much turf lawn they really need, as it is sterile to wildlife and pollinators, is non-native and takes a remarkable amount of time, effort, cost and chemical applications to thrive.  To this end, you could take a look at this page from our website: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/lawn-alternatives/. There are many salt-tolerant shrubs that are native to Maryland like Itea, Button Bush, American Hollies, Sweet Bay Magnolia and others that would be attractive and be able to take the occasional flooding without issue.    Christine

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks so much for responding. To that end I assume there is no grass like fescue, bermuda, etc that forms like a conventional lawn that would work??  Thanks again BillOn Mon, Oct 28, 2024 at 10:47 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Unfortunately, there isn't really a good choice. Even some turf types that say they have some salt tolerance aren't really suited for soil that floods. Bermuda grass will not thrive in Maryland- it is a more southern species. (Not to be confused with the problematic perennial grassy weed referred to interchangeably as Wiregrass here). This page from Clemson Extension explains some reasons why that is so: https://hgic.clemson.edu/factsheet/saltwater-intrusion-remediation-on-turfgrass/ Note that most of the grasses mentioned won't work well here, and we tend to think that even if the salt levels aren't too high for, say, zoysia, the root zone flooding itself might cause root rot or enough stress that the lawn would still struggle.    Christine

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: THANKS FOR THE HELP --PROMPT RESPONSE

goal: Identify the caterpillar species found on the C&O trail.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
We recently found a caterpillar on the C&O trail.  Regrettably we did not get an image of it.  The larvae was at least three possibly four inches long and stoutly built. It was covered in brown/black branching setae fairly dense.
The were a pair of short horns on the head itself that looked like the stereotypical devil's horns. A single row of horns ran down the center of the back.
At the thoraxic end there were a series of bright yellow green elliptical panels free of setae.
We were at pains to remove it from the bicycle path and trail lest it be crushed.  in doing so it fell from the branch it was crawling on before we could get an image.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: That sounds like such a cool find. It was great that you wanted him out of harms way. Could it be that you met a so-called Hickory Horned Devil caterpillar? They are one of, if not our largest native caterpillars, and they turn into the Regal Walnut Moth. Take a look:  https://www.pubs.ext.vt.edu/ENTO/ENTO-20/ENTO-20.html   Christine

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: No, this caterpillar was covered in setae very much like the "wooly bear".  The horns were minute and barely visible when looking directly into the "face". There were similar spines in a single row down the back. There is a single row ellipses along the flanks near the head "()" similar in color to the hickory devil's hide. In fact they were almost the same size as () in trebuchet. I do not believe that it was either an alien creature brought here by the lizard people who have infiltrated our government nor something that has escaped from the North Polar entrance in our hollow earth due to global warming and the melting polar ice.  Let us just say that I am skeptical about either notion. I know I have not seen a majority of insects, I grew up in Michigan and have been relearning to do as to what constitutes "local", but I am still surprised and excited when I find something I have neither read about or seen.Again apologies for no photo.Art

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Art,  That sounds like a fun find, though unfortunately it's hard for us to guess as to what it was. Few species attain that size, and those that do tend to be members of the Sphinx (Sphingidae) or Wild Silk Moth (Saturniidae) families. The former tend not to have bristles or spines, save for a few horns (if any) on their bodies, so that leaves Saturniidae (also not generally densely spiny/bristly), or perhaps a caterpillar a bit smaller than the size you describe (like a Buck Moth, Tussock Moth, or Dagger Moth species larva, though those are not that big). The elliptical features you mention are probably the spiracles, which are breathing pores found on the sides of the body in all insects, but which can take on this () appearance in caterpillars. While all caterpillars will have them in that general shape, they won't be prominent in some species.  Miri

goal: Determine whether the manzanita and currant plants will survive after being poisoned.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
3 weeks ago someone poisoned our front yard. The flowers all died but I thought the manzanita and currant would survive but they are looking worse - more dead leaves daily. 
I would like to know if I should remove them or if they might come back in the spring.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your question, Annette.  How disrespectful of your property and native plants, to boot!  Unfortunately, without removing some of the lower limbs to see if tissue is still viable, we can't predict whether these woody plants will recover.  And, without knowing the chemical that was applied, it's impossible to know whether it was topical (just covered and killed the leaves), or was systemic (absorbed by the plants and translocated to the roots).  I'd suggest you let them be this winter and, in the spring, wait for new foliage, plus bending the branches to see if they are still pliable.  If they all break off, the plants are dead.  Good luck!

goal: Keep pests such as snakes, mice, and moles/voles away from the foundation of the house to prevent them from entering the basement furnace room.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Is there a type of shrub I can plant near my home which repels pests like bugs, mice, moles and snakes?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: No, there is no plant capable of repelling all of those organisms. Instead, managing habitat to discourage rodents from visiting (by keeping firewood away from the house, for example, or not having bark mulch or leaf mulched piled against the foundation) will be of more use, and sealing any gaps/cracks in exterior walls can also go along way towards keeping them out of a home. Snakes go where their prey is (and very much try to avoid conflicts with people), so by keeping mice or rats at bay, you're less likely to have snakes. (Though snakes are varied and several small species eat other things, like slugs/snails, worms, and insects, and are incapable of harming people.) Snakes are great pest control in home landscapes and it would be best to let them roam outside so they can consume pests before their populations become large. This includes rodents that can carry ticks that pick up Lyme Disease and other pathogens.  Most insects are not pests (for people or plants), and many actually are beneficial, helping to eat the insects that are pests. Insects that are pests take specific approaches to control, so they would need to be identified first. For example, mosquito control efforts would not be the same as for carpenter bees, so there is no single way to repel all of them. Broad-spectrum pesticides that kill a variety of insects also kill the beneficial ones, including pollinators (bees, butterflies), fireflies, and those that prey on pests.  Moles and voles are often confused for each other, as both make small holes in the soil and can create tunnels throughout parts of the yard. Moles eat worms, insects, and similar organisms; voles eat plant matter (roots, sometimes whole plants for perennials and annuals). Both tend to go away on their own in just a season or two because they are short-lived and prey for a variety of animals, including foxes, snakes, owls, and hawks. Do not use any poison baits to control them (because this can injure or kill those other animals), but if needed, lethal traps can capture moles and voles to reduce the population faster.  These resources for moles, voles, and mice may be useful:Penn State -- MolesOhio State -- Mole ControlUniversity of Nebraska -- Controlling Vole DamageCornell -- Dealing with Mice in Your Home (video)Cornell -- Managing Mice and RatsPenn State -- Is There a Mouse in the House? Eliminate Mice with IPMMaryland DNR -- Maryland Snakes (can help with ID, or you can send us photos if you see a snake you'd like to identify) - Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks. I guess my question was pretty broad. You see, my townhouse backs up to woods. These snakes mice and mole / voles are somehow getting inside my basement furnace room. There is nothing on that level for them to eat. I was trying to get specifics on how to keep them away from the foundation of the house where they likely get in my home. Perhaps I should consult a contractor as the exterminators I hired months ago are unsuccessful in keeping the critters out of my home.  Just thought you should know the entire picture.   Sincerely, Christine

goal: Understand and address the user's concern about high grub activity in Michigan in 2024.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Are you hearing anything on abnormally high grub activity this year in Michigan? If so, any publications to share with homeowners on what is causing this to be so high in 2024.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: As a Master Gardener volunteer I have not received any information that grub populations are high in 2024.  My thought is that there might be more Japanese beetle grubs due to the wetter than normal summer we had (because they like irrigated turf).  But that would be somewhat offset by a probable decrease in the European Chafer grub population as they prefer drier turf settings. Considering that October has been warmer than normal,  grub activity could extend later into the fall before temperatures cool enough for them to go into hibernation until spring. I have asked my local Consumer Horticultural Educator if he has heard/read anything.  No reply yet.  If he has a positive answer I'll pass it on to you in another email. I'm assuming if you are asking the question you think/know you have a grub problem.  Having a healthy turf is the first line of defense against grubs.  I recommend doing a soil test if you haven't done one in two years. You will learn more about your soil including soil type, pH, nutrient levels and more. Knowing the type and fertility of your soil is the starting point to establishing & maintaining a strong turf that can resist diseases, moss, weeds, insects/grubs and look great at an optimal cost. More info here: Don't Guess-Soil Test-MSU and MSU Home Soil Test-self mailer Info on grub control in the attached links: How to Choose & Apply Grub Control Products-MSU - how to check for grubs and what to do when, if too many are found.... Current Insecticide Approaches for White Grubs-UMass  Take Control of Lawn Grubs w-o chemicals-PSU  Managing grubs in Turf Milky Spore-Illinois

dialog_context.text: Thank you!   Regards,   Mike   •••••••••     From: ask=<personal data hidden> On Behalf Of Ask Extension Sent: Friday, October 25, 2024 9:05 PM To: Mike Dzurenko  Subject: Re: 2024 Grub Activity (#0158478)     You don't often get email from <personal data hidden>. goal: Identify and understand the behavior and characteristics of the 'booie woogie' beech aphids observed in the woods.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
'booie woogie' beech aphids seen in the woods at Adkins arboretum. What type are these?
Are they Grylloprociphilus imbricator? Are they the type that over winter in the roots of bald cypress? Or do the do something else? What is it about the Bald Cypress that attracts them? Will they choose a different tree if the Bald cypress isn't near by?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: The Beech Blight Aphids (Grylloprociphilus imbricator, as you  noted) that have several other common names are widespread and native to our region. They are the woolly aphid species seen congregating on beech branches. Yes, they can overwinter in the root zone of Baldcypress, though we don't know how often this occurs in Maryland (it would be difficult to survey, since a researcher would presumably have to get lucky and dig in the right spots to find a colony).  As far as what attracts them to Baldcypress as the alternate host we don't know (other than "smelling" chemical cues to find the trees, we don't know what benefit that species provides), but it's not uncommon for several other aphid species to alternate between unrelated plant species over the course of a year. For example, the Witchhazel Cone Gall Aphid that uses both witchhazel and river birch as hosts. Given the host specificity, the use of any other substitute host plant is probably not likely, but we don't have that level of detail about their life cycle.  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks Miri.One more thing. Is the genus species identified correctly in the photos. Grylloprociphilus imbricator,? VivianOn Mon, Oct 21, 2024 at 1:35 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

known.behavior: congregating on beech branches, can overwinter in the root zone of Baldcypress
known.uncertainty about attraction: unknown what attracts them to Baldcypress

missing: Confirmation if the aphids in the photos are indeed Grylloprociphilus imbricator

expected_output: Can you confirm if the aphids in your photos match the description of Grylloprociphilus imbricator?

goal: Determine the health of a Silver Maple tree and decide if it requires professional evaluation.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: i noticed that areas of bark are coming off silver maple

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: We can't make a diagnosis from the photos of flaking bark, but if the canopy was showing signs of dieback earlier in the year (once the leaves start shedding, it's hard to judge) or if mushrooms are growing out of the trunk, then the tree should be evaluated by a certified arborist. Some bark detachment as trees age can be normal; it depends on the tree, though large flaking pieces of bark aren't typical for Silver Maple. Arborists can't treat or cure every condition, but they can look for characteristic symptoms and sources of tree stress that might be able to be alleviated. Even if there is a portion of wood decay in the trunk (one possible cause of bark loss), it doesn't necessarily doom the tree, as they have ways of compartmentalizing it internally (which won't be visible from outside the trunk) so decay does not spread further.  Miri

goal: Ensure raspberry plant receives adequate chill hours for successful fruiting next year.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi, I have a raspberry plant that I grew a container this year on the deck. I’m wondering if I need to leave it outside to get the proper amount of chill hours? Or would it work OK to leave it in an attached garage that averages between 30 and 45° all winter long? I am in an association so it would work better if I’m able to keep it in the garage. But I know if you don’t get enough chill hours, you won’t get any raspberries next year. Thanks in advance.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your question. Chill hours are needed to help the raspberry plant go into dormancy and still flower and set fruit in the spring. Most of the literature about chill hours is about raspberries planted in the ground, but they can be successfully grown in containers. Since the recommended chill temps are 32-45F, it will depend on what variety of raspberry plant you have (summer bearing or fall bearing). Hopefully you chose a hardier variety able to survive a cold winter even inside a garage. According to Penn State Extension, most raspberries need 80-100 chill hours to enter dormancy. Not knowing where you're located, I would make sure to bring in inside if you get a hard frost to protect your plant. I would also think your garage will provide your plant with enough chill hours to help it to become dormant. Here is an article explaining this further: Can Raspberry Plants Survive Frost in Winter? (Coldest Temp) – greenupside

dialog_context.text: Thank you for your reply, it was very helpful along with the link.The variety of Raspberries I am growing is Latham. : ) From: ask=<personal data hidden> On Behalf Of Ask ExtensionSent: Saturday, October 19, 2024 2:30 PMTo: lisa.peterson Subject: Re: Raspberry chill hours (#0158125)

goal: Manage and maintain a healthy lawn based on soil test results.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
We just received results of a soil test of our lawn and have a few questions.

Mow as high as possible – how high is ideal?

 What problem(s) could be associated with a lawn high in phosphorus and/or potassium? 
 
Our lawn tested Excessive for Magnesium.  What problem(s) could be associated with this?

Thank you, Larry Mindell

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Larry,  Thanks for reaching out to the EMG helpline! One of my colleagues requested a copy of your soil test so we could examine the results. Apologies for the slight delay in responding - we just received the copy yesterday.  Regarding the optimal turf grass length, it's best to select the highest height you find suitable in appearance - this is generally around 3 inches. Lawns cut shorter than this will have shorter and less prolific root systems. You can also leave clippings on the lawn to add nitrogen back to the soil, which can minimize the need to add other fertilizers.  Excessive phosphorus, potassium, and magnesium should not cause detrimental effects to your lawn. It's a good idea to be aware of the levels as you have don't with this soil test and reduce application of additional nutrients. It's worth mentioning that excessive phosphorus can cause environmental issues when runoff enters waterways. Considering a few of your nutrients are high or excessive, you can plan not to add any additional fertilizer or compost to your lawns. You can test again next season to see if any adjustments are needed.

dialog_context.text: Jessica,   Thank you very much for your thorough and well-written reply!  Very helpful.   In your response you suggest not adding any fertilizer or compost since our lawn has optimum or high levels of all important nutrients.  Is what you’re saying true for nitrogen as well, assuming clippings are left on the lawn?   Larry   From: ask=<personal data hidden> On Behalf Of Ask Extension Sent: Tuesday, October 22, 2024 6:01 PM To: Larry Mindell  Subject: Re: Existing Lawn (#0158082)

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Pete, this is from one of the pages I sent you: "Pine needle scale, Chionaspis pinifoliae, is a common insect pest of pines in Missouri. It is most frequently found on Mugo, Scotch (Scots), and Ponderosa pine but will also infest Austrian, red, or white pine and most spruces. Light infestations often go unnoticed and cause little damage. As the population increases, needles become covered with the white-scale insects, which suck juices from the needles. A heavy infestation can cause whole branches to die, or in severe cases, kill the plants." Thanks.

goal: Revitalize and maintain a healthy lawn with tall fescue grass.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Good afternoon.
My back yard was sodded with tall fescue two years ago. It looked fine until September, when I returned from being gone for six weeks. I know that it can do dormant in the heat, but it has continued to look bad (see photo) even after the regular rain of mid-late September and after I applied weed and feed. Do you have some thoughts? I don't want to have to resod.
Thanks.
P.S. Why do my hostas get like this every year? (See photo.)

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: The drought status many Maryland counties experienced this past summer was intense enough to have killed some lawn grasses, rather than just induce dormancy. If the lawn wasn't able to be irrigated periodically in your absence, that might have been the cause of dead zones within the lawn. An outbreak of disease (Brown Patch being one possibility) can't be ruled-out, but most areas were so dry that a fungal issue was less likely.  The only option if no new growth has appeared by now (or, really, a few weeks ago) is to re-seed or re-sod those patches. Dead grass should be raked off and seed or sod put down as needed. However, since we are into the second half of October, it's a bit late to try seeding, as the seedlings might not have enough time to establish by the time nights freeze and the days get too short to support growth. If you try seeding, put down seed as soon as possible and monitor them carefully for watering needs, as seed is intolerant of drying out for long during the germination and establishment phases. Covering seeded areas with row cover might give them a few degrees of temperature insulation that can help them catch up on growth. A safer bet this late into lawn season, though, is to put down sod instead. It will also need attention to watering as it roots in, but at least it saves you time in getting new grass established before it gets too cold and we have too little daylight. Maryland Certified Sod will have the best quality, if it's still available.  For the future, we don't recommend the use of weed & feed products since they necessitate putting down fertilizer and herbicide at the same time, which doesn't allow you to customize each to what the lawn actually needs. A laboratory soil test will help determine what nutrients the lawn might be lacking (if any), which also determines which type of fertilizer (with or without phosphorus) is legal to use, as Maryland has a lawn fertilizer law that restricts phosphorus use only to lawns whose soil test shows a deficiency. This limits stormwater and Bay pollution, though it also is cost-saving since you're not applying a nutrient the lawn doesn't need if phosphorus levels are sufficient as-is. Soil testing also evaluates acidity (pH), in case lime applications would benefit the lawn. The latest legal date for fertilizer application is Nov. 15, so that leaves little time to apply one fertilization to new seed or sod if it's sown/laid late, though the nutrients from the prior fertilization might suffice without adding more.  To determine which herbicides (if any) are best to use (and at what timing) for lawn weeds, the weed ID needs to be determined first. You can explore our lawn weed web pages to find the species most commonly causing problems in lawns, or you can send us photos for ID if you can't find a match. A healthy, vigorous, dense lawn will need little in the way of herbicide application, since the turf will out-compete most weeds before they get a chance to establish.  The holes in the Hosta foliage look like classic slug/snail damage; Hostas are a favored food for them, among other annuals and perennials. No intervention is needed this season since the plants will soon be going dormant, but information on the linked page can help you minimize damage in future summers.  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks very much.We leave on Nov. 13 and will return in April. Is there any preparation I can do for the winter in advance of reseeding next spring? On Thu, Oct 17, 2024 at 12:31 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Probably not, though it may depend on which lawn weeds have been significant problems in the past. Some require a pre-emergent (if you were to use any herbicide to manage them) to be put down earlier than April (probably March, but it depends on the weed species). Otherwise, no, lawns would not need much intervention between those dates. (Nor the hostas.)  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks agaiin for all your time. I just want to be clear what I should do from here:In the spring, cut it very short and reseed. Do I need to use fescue seed or will the Scotts FastGrass be ok? Don't prep with any herbicide.And assuming the grass gets growing, do I fertilize?Last, I have a product called Winter Survival by Jonathan Green. Should I put that down before I go back to Florida?On Fri, Oct 18, 2024 at 10:29 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Cutting existing lawn short before reseeding helps the seed get enough light to germinate well, though it's not necessary to mow lower than usual. We don't see a product online listed by the name FastGrass...did you mean Scotts Rapid Grass instead? (Of which there are several different formulations, so we still don't know which exact one you are referring to.)  The proportions of grass seed type will be listed on the bag for each option on the market. The Scotts products that we think you are referring to are probably not customized to be locally-proven varieties for the Mid-Atlantic, with our challenging growing conditions for turf, though you can cross-check what varieties the label does include with the recommended turfgrass cultivars on the linked UMD publication. Ideally, you want as many cultivars as possible in the bag to be included on that published list.  Quick-to-germinate filler in some seed blends tends to be perennial ryegrass, which you do not want in proportions higher than 5 to 15% of the mix due to its greater disease susceptibility compared to tall fescue. We would suspect that a seed blend advertising rapid growth uses a higher amount of ryegrass, but it's hard to tell as we can't look up the product label.  The web page Lawn Fertilizer Schedule that we shared previously lists the application rate (based on nitrogen) and recommended application times of year, so a spring application would be made around May, if it's needed. The Winter Survival product you mention looks like it has zero phosphorus [P], which is good (and legally required unless a lawn soil test shows a P deficiency). It could be applied now if the lawn needed a boost and if the weed-and-feed you already applied has had enough time to work. (How many weeks ago was it applied? If it was just earlier this month, then the lawn probably does not need another dose of any fertilizer before the Nov. 15 cutoff date.) You'll still need to apply it at a dose compliant with the lawn fertilizer schedule, so too much nitrogen [N] isn't applied at once (no more than 0.9 lb. per 1,000 sq. ft. of total nitrogen per application).  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Milkweed is toxic whether it is in the dry hay or growing in the pasture. dialog_context.text: This magnificent 30 year old maple (a hybrid of red and silver maple) is on the county strip along the street.  It began to shed large sections of bark this summer. There has been much less rain than usual recently, but there are other trees in the same vicinity that aren't shedding bark.  Yesterday I noticed an infestation of lantern flies on the tree (as well as on neighboring trees), but the flies weren't apparent when I first noticed the shedding bark, and the other trees with lantern flies aren't shedding bark.  I'd be very grateful to have the tree diagnosed/treated/saved.  Thanks!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: We are not able to open your first photo, but the second photo shows a large limb and a smaller one that is essentially hollow and is rotted out, which happened long ago. In areas where tree falls would not threaten people or property leaving dead or dying trees standing has good environmental value for wildlife and other organisms. You likely hear or see songbirds and woodpeckers hunting insects, nesting in the holes or using them for shelter in the winter.   Shedding large sections of bark isn't normal on healthy limbs, and along a street, it is worth investigating. How does the overall leafy canopy look?  This page can help you to gauge the health of the tree: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/how-do-you-decide-when-remove-tree/ The last couple of growing seasons have had periods of intense heat and prolonged drought which have stressed even our large landscape trees. Given the tree's importance to you, we suggest having a tree health expert, a.k.a., a certified arborist (not just a tree cutter), assess the health and stability of the tree. Most larger tree companies have one on staff or you can search for one at the credentialing agency at http://www.treesaregood.org   Christine

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you Christine! If I might, here are a couple of followup questions.  1) Does the lanternfly infestation need remediation?  2) Does the homeowner or the county (Montgomery in my case) pay for an arborist to diagnose and treat a "street" tree? I'm responsible for mowing the strip where the tree is, but the county occasionally comes by to prune the trees where they overhang the street and interfere with trash trucks, etc.Here, below, is the photo that wouldn't open.  It shows the shedding bark and, higher up, the lanternflies.Again, many thanks!On Wed, Oct 16, 2024 at 1:36 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

goal: Successfully transplant two Kentucky coffeetree volunteers to more appropriate locations.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I have two Kentucky coffeetree "volunteers".  One is about 9-10 feet tall.  The other about 15 inches.  Neither is in an appropriate location.  I have a woodland edge for the large one, but I am nervous about digging it out, as we may accidentally damage the tap root.  I believe I may be able to move the little one to a pot, for planting later in a better spot.  Is it fine to do this all in Oct./Nov.?  (We're in Northern Illinois.). How long should I expect the tap root to be; do I have any hope of getting it out intact?  And where should I keep the smaller one during winter? Maybe bury it up to planting depth in the ground? I really would like to save these trees.  Thank you for any advice you can offer.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Elaine,  I have consulted with one of our Extension Forestry Specialists on this, and I have included a synopsis of his response below.  -- I would suspect that the trees they are considering to transplant are likely root suckers if there is a mature K. coffeetree nearby. Transplanting the small trees should be fairly simple, however, to ensure the highest chance of success it would be beneficial to root prune this fall and move the trees in the spring of 2025. If these trees are indeed root suckers, then the likelihood they have a deep taproot is very low, but you would want to get the largest rootball possible to include the largest number of lateral roots. They make shovels designed for root pruning, but most long round spades should work fine. Root pruning should be done as soon as possible to allow the tree more time to develop roots within the rootball zone, which is dependent on the size of the trees.  The general rule is a minimum of 12 inches in diameter for trees in inch or less in trunk diameter.  For each additional inch of trunk diameter at chest height (if it is that tall), add another 12 inches to the rootball zone diameter. However, the rootball size for the 9 ft trees can quickly become unreasonable for a DIY project and may require a professional with a tree spade. I would recommend a minimum of a 36" diameter rootball for a 9 ft tree, which could easily weigh 1000 lbs. For the larger tree, they might consider attempting to bare-root transplant the tree in the spring to minimize weight concerns. An airspade can be rented, or hand excavation in conjunction with a pressurized water stream can also be effective for bare-rooting the trees.  Roots can then be followed and severed cleanly with a sharp pair of pruners. Moving a bare-rooted tree will be much easier compared to a large root ball with soil. I hope this is helpful.  --  I've also attached an article from Penn State Extension with some information on root pruning and more for transplanting trees and shrubs from one location to another.  So, to summarize, it seems best to wait until early spring.  However, the root pruning can and should be done immediately.  The simplest method is to use a round spade and cut straight down in a circular pattern around the rootball zone.  A trench method is also described in the attached article, but that may take more time, effort, and materials.  When transplanting next spring, be sure to cut just outside your root prune cut so you capture the new feeder roots without damaging them.  For the larger tree, you might consider having it moved by a professional with a tree spade, or taking the time to expose bare roots that can be cut and the tree moved as a bare root transplant.  This would still require several people, perhaps some machinery, and some caution to move safely.  I hope this helps.  Please let me know if you have any follow-up questions.   Regards, Talon Becker Illinois Extension

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hello Talon,  Thank you for your detailed and excellent input addressing my volunteers.  I will make the appropriate preparations for a spring transplant of the larger tree.  Upon further examination, I think the little guy is not a coffee tree at all.  As to the larger specimen, it is about 1 and 1/2 inch in diameter at the ground and no more than an inch at chest height.  I've attempted to attach photos, but don't seem to have succeeded.   I'm not quite persuaded that the tree is the product of a sucker, as the long since removed parent tree was more than 80 feet away.  Would that even be possible? The seed capsule on the other hand may have been in the soil for quite a number of years, and degraded?  Seems miraculous, either way!  In any event, I will attempt to send another photo as a smaller file. I will turn my attention to the attachment you sent, and look forward to your reply. Thank you once again, Elaine Derer

known.tree sizes: One tree is about 9-10 feet tall and another is about 15 inches tall
known.concerns: Worried about damaging the tap root during transplant
known.current plan: Root pruning in fall and professional help for larger tree in spring

missing: Confirmation of whether the larger tree is indeed a root sucker or from a seed

expected_output: Is there a mature Kentucky coffeetree nearby that could have produced root suckers, or do you have reason to believe these trees grew from seeds?
title: Transplanting Kentucky coffeetree guidance

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Hello there,

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: The white particles on the leaves are not eggs; they are debris from the spent flowers as they shed parts that have expired due to the age of the flower, which is perfectly normal. The plants do not appear to be wilting, but do make sure that they are periodically monitored for watering needs, both while still in their pots and after planting. (The page linked above pertains to in-ground plants, as potted plants tend to dry out faster than those in the ground.) As deciduous plants, they will soon be shedding leaves for winter, especially once we have a few overnight frosts. If you intend to plant them in the ground (recommended for their best health and performance), try to get them in soon so they can start establishing roots before the soil surface freezes more consistently.  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you Miri so much for your help. So relieved I thought it was a plague, and the nursery guy told me it was aphids?We are planning to put them in the ground sooner than later.You are always very helpful.Warm regards,Susy

goal: Determine the cause of the lawn and flower bed damage and find an effective, non-chemical solution to restore and protect the lawn.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I have a tiny patch of grass lawn in the city, neighborhood of Mt. Adams, Cincinnati. I watered the grass in what I thought to be adequate to deal with our summer drought. I do not use much at all in the way of chemicals - pesticides, weed killer, fertilizer - trying to be chemical free.  Over the past 6-8 weeks, the lawn has been destroyed - it appears almost to have been plowed up.  It began as a few small "holes" about 2 inches wide and 1-2 inches deep, scattered around. Gradually progressed and now - There is literally no grass remaining. We do have ground hogs & opossums in the area, but I have not seen raccoons in a very long while.  From the photos attached, do you have any idea what might have caused this damage?  My flower beds, which are well-mulched, seem to have digging activity lately, also.  Thank you.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Glenda, something has made a mess of your yard. Yard damage like this is caused by moles or voles or grubs. Moles dig tunnels just below the surface, leaving raised ridges and mounds of dirt (molehills). Their tunneling can uproot grass and disturb the lawn’s appearance. They are searching for earthworms, grubs, and other soil invertebrates. Voles create small surface tunnels that leave behind pathways or “runways” of dead grass. They chew on roots and bulbs, leading to dying patches in the lawn. They feed on vegetation, roots and seeds. Grubs (the larvae of beetles like Japanese beetles or chafer beetles) feed on grassroots, causing large brown patches that can be easily lifted because the roots are destroyed. Grubs are more likely to cause lawn damage in the spring and early summer.  From the photo it looks like there are tunnels and molehills in your yard which are characteristic signs of moles. So I suspect moles are causing the problem. Moles can be controlled using repellants, baits or traps. I am including a factsheet on moles which describes their activities and controls in more detail. Sometimes both moles and voles are present at the same time so I am also sending a factsheet on voles. Also with moles once they have exhausted their food supply in a yard they will move on. If you use a pesticide to control them please read and follow the directions on the label for effectiveness and safety.  It is probably too late in the year for traditional reseeding of your yard.  But there is a practice called dormant seeding (seeing over winter) which might be something for you to consider.  It gets the grass started sooner next spring.  Look over the factsheet and see if it might be a fit for you.  And one more factsheet on the best trufgrass types for Ohio (yeah we like factsheets). You can take the turfgrass sheet to a garden center to get a good seed mix for your area. Thank you for using Ask Extension. Moles Voles Dormant Deeding Turfgrass for Ohio

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for this information. Thinking back - it seems like, in spite of my watering the grass during the drought, it died out anyway, & now I wonder if that was due to some insect that killed it from underneath. The damage I'm seeing is severe - as I mentioned, my little lawn appears to have been "plowed up" from underneath - I really don't like the idea of chemicals, but in addition to winter seeding, should I apply some type of pesticide to the area?  I don't want to harm wildlife or pollinators.  Also - whatever is causing all this problem is INVISIBLE!  I check the area during daytime & also after dark, & I've never seen a rodent or anything!  And - now in the bordering plant/flower beds which are mulched, I am seeing digging around.  Never experienced ANYTHING like this before! Thank you -

known.damage description: small holes, severe damage, digging in flower beds

missing: Whether the user has considered or can conduct a soil test to check for grubs or other underground pests

goal: Prevent sod webworms from destroying the user's lawn.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
I believe I have an infestation of sod webworms in my yard.  I have tall turf fescue.  At first, the yard had small patches of dried looking grass.  Then, they became bigger.  I was told to treat for fungus.  I did.  They got bigger.  I saw a lot of white moths coming up out of the yard in the evenings when walking through the yard or watering.  I keep my yard mowed to the highest in the summer months.  I aerate and reseed every year and apply starter fertilizer.  A grub application was applied in early June.  By fall, my grass was gone in big patches.  HELP!  How do I prevent these insects from destroying my lawn?

Thanks your any help you can provide.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello, It does sound like there is a good chance that you have had a sod webworm problem this past year. Sod webworms will typically overwinter in your yard and so can be a problem in the same areas they were in this past year. This is somewhat uncommon for insects as many will fly elsewhere.  You will likely need to apply an insecticide that is targeted at the webworms. A few insecticides that are good for this include Capture, Mustang, and Lorsban. Before you apply these insecticides, heavily water your yard (1/2 inch of water) to bring the caterpillars close to the surface. You will also want to cut the grass a bit lower than you typically do to remove most of the canopy and get the insecticide closer to where the caterpillars are. I am attaching a link for a good article on this topic from the University of Nebraska Department of Entomology. Good luck!Robby https://entomology.unl.edu/turfent/documnts/swebwrms.shtml
