goal: Successfully revive and maintain a sourdough starter.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Hi I recently attended a sourdough class on Monday in Gilford. I put the starter we were given in a glass make for sourdough. It has been on my kitchen counter since Thursday and I am not seeing any growth. Not sure what to do.
Thank you for any advice
Kathe Glauser

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Kathe,  Thanks for reaching out to the UNH Extension Infoline. Thanks for coming to the class and I hope you enjoyed it! So, you should be feeding the starter every 12 hours. This means discarding all but 113g and adding that to 113g white flour, and 113g water. The first few days of feeding, you might not see much growth, but be consistent and it will gain vigor.  One of the handouts I gave was instructions on feeding and maintaining. You can refer to that if you get stuck. Here is a link to that as well.  If you are following the instructions and still don't see any activity in a few day, let me know and I can troubleshoot with you.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi SeanYes, I did enjoy the class although I was a little lost lol. It has been sitting out on the counter since Thursday. Is it too late to start feeding it?Thanks again, KatheSent from my iPad Kathe On Oct 14, 2024, at 10:31 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Also, I did purchase a scale. What should I put it in to weigh it? I’m thinking the glass jar is too heavy. Thanks again. Sorry to be a pain.Sent from my iPad Kathe On Oct 14, 2024, at 10:47 AM, Kathe Glauser wrote:﻿Hi SeanYes, I did enjoy the class although I was a little lost lol. It has been sitting out on the counter since Thursday. Is it too late to start feeding it?Thanks again, KatheSent from my iPad KatheOn Oct 14, 2024, at 10:31 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Kathe,  It isn't too late! I would give it a feeding as soon as possible though. If you see any liquid on top, you can just mix that in or pour it off, either is fine.  For measuring with your scale, I use two glass jars like I showed at the class and just alternate between them. Glass is fine to use on a scale, just be sure to tare it out after you put the jar on the scale, otherwise you'll have to do the quick math of the weight of the jar plus the starter, flour and water.  My process goes something like this- Grab my scale and my clean jar. Place clean jar on scale and tare it. This should leave you with zero on the scale. I then take my starter from the last feeding, mix it up a bit, and measure out 113g right into the clean jar on the scale. If you accidentally put a little to much in, just scoop it back out until you're close to 113g.  Then, I tare it again and using a small scoop, I scoop my flour into the jar until it reaches 113g (give or take a gram or two). At this point, I have 113g of starter and 113g of flour in the jar. Next, I'll take that off the scale and get two measuring cups. I use silicone measuring cups because they're easy to pour. The first one, I'll put on the scale and tare it. The other I put about a half cup of water in and then pour into the measuring cup on the scale until it reaches 113g. Then I'll pour that into the starter/flour mixture and mix it all up until smooth. I hope that isn't confusing! Please ask if you have more questions!

On Thu, Oct 10, 2024, 9:54 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Butterfly Bush (Buddleia davidii) is an invasive species in the mid-Atlantic that we discourage gardeners from growing. They tolerate pruning well, and it's best done in late winter or early spring (March, more or less, for areas like central Maryland), not autumn. They can be cut back fairly drastically since they bloom on new growth (so no flower buds are present on branches during winter) and non-dwarf cultivars are rapid growers. Exactly how far to cut them back depends on the preferences of the gardener, but pruning to within a foot or two of the ground should be fine.  Miri

goal: Effectively treat and manage the white spots on the crape myrtle tree.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi, there. I live in Olney, Md and came back after a vacation to see these white spots all over my crape Myrtle! Tree stands alone and is south-facing with good drainage. Can you tell me what they are and what, if anything, I need to do about them? They are not moving.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: This looks like a relatively new pest in Maryland called Crapemyrtle Bark Scale. Here is our page about them:  https://extension.umd.edu/resource/crapemyrtle-bark-scale-home-gardens/ The good news is that you are seeing it early and can consider scrubbing off some of them (that you can reach) with a brush and soapy water. Since they are new here, we are still learning about their life cycle in our area but we were happily surprised this year to find them being controlled by beneficial insects, especially the larval stage of lady beetles. See the link above- they look a good deal like the scale but are larger, more fluffy and have legs and can move quickly.   Christine

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you. I gave the trunk (and branches I could reach) a good scrub with soapy (Dawn) water. Then I rinsed with the jet setting to clean the bark, and most came off. Fingers crossed.  Should I spray again with anything or was rinsing okay?Thanks,Tami

goal: Determine the best course of action for managing Purple loosestrife in the user's garden.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I would like some recommendations on my Purple loosestrife.  Is it safe to have, Should it be removed, Could it be transplanted to another location or should it?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Margaret, Many years ago, I discovered this lovely, spiked purple flower growing in my garden. I didn't plant it, so I thanked the birds for dropping the seeds of this flower. It wasn't until a few years later when I was taking MSU Master Gardener training that I learned I had purple loosestrife. Even though I didn't live near a river or lake, I was told that I should remove it from my garden because of its aggressive behavior and impact on other plants.  A question for you: You didn't provide a photo, so are you sure it's purple loosestrife? Some plants mimic it. How did it get in your garden? How long have you had it? You probably didn't purchase this in a nursery. This plant is restricted in Michigan.  The following definition of purple loosestrife is from the MISIN (Midwest Invasive Species Information Network). The MISIN keeps track of invasive species in the Midwest. Description: This species is restricted under Michigan law; attractive but persistent weed; spreads vigorously in moist soil conditions; crowds out native wetland plant species. https://www.misin.msu.edu/facts/detail/?project=misin&id=32&common=Purple+loosestrife  If a species is prohibited or restricted, it is unlawful to possess, introduce, import, sell or offer that species for sale as a live organism, except under certain circumstances.  https://www.michigan.gov/invasives/id-report/prohibitedrestricted  Purple loosestrife reproduces mostly by seed. Each stem of the plant contains about 200,000 tiny seeds. Since the plant may contain at least 5 - 10 stems, a single plant can produce over 1 million seeds a year. These seeds can stay dormant in the soil for years.   The following is from Penn State Extension: "The tiny seeds, about the size of ground pepper, are transported by water, wind, and feathers and fur of aquatic birds and mammals. Seeds that stick to muddy footgear, boats, boat trailers and vehicle treads can travel far from the original site to spread this purple menace.The seeds may remain viable for many years when submerged, waiting for the opportunity to sprout. Suddenly, during a dry summer, the seeds may germinate. Seed production, dispersal and germination are so effective that young seedlings can completely replace native vegetation."  https://extension.psu.edu/purple-loosestrife-in-pennsylvania  Finally, if you wish to keep this plant in your garden, read this from MSU Extension:  "If managing purple loosestrife in a location, monitoring the flowering progress can be helpful when deciding about control. Pulling plants before they are done blooming and begin producing seeds can help prevent them from spreading. Purple loosestrife can reproduce asexually from cuttings or pieces of rootstock. Due to this, it is best to burn the pulled plants or dispose of them in closed plastic bags in the trash. If treating with a foliar herbicide, treating after peak bloom around August can be effective. Permits are often required when using an herbicide near bodies of water to help ensure proper use and protection of our water resources. Visit the EGLE website for more information."   https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/drive-by-botany-purple-loosestrife-and-spotted-knapweed  I hope this information is helpful, but please don't hesitate to contact us again if you have questions or need more information.  Have a great fall!

known.user's concern: Safety and management of the plant

missing: How the Purple loosestrife was introduced to the garden
How long the Purple loosestrife has been in the garden

expected_output: How did the Purple loosestrife get introduced to your garden, and how long has it been growing there?
title: Purple Loosestrife

dialog_context.speaker: expert

The section on disease speaks to crop rotation for disease reduction. Have you done that? Does your garden get enough sun for these crops? How many years have you had success before this problem started? If the advice is lab testing, here is the OSU Plant Clinic website.

dialog_context.speaker: user

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Lanternfly was first detected in the U.S. (in Pennsylvania) ten years ago, and has been spreading since then. Almost all counties in Maryland have at least some populations of lanternfly, though some have a greater abundance than others. While they can fly and jump, the primary means of spread over greater distances has likely been "hitchhiking" on vehicles, shipments, trains, trucks, and so forth. Egg masses (the only life stage that survives the winter) can be laid on just about anything (it was probably an egg mass on a pallet of landscaping stone that started it all), including patio furniture covers, car tires, deck rails, nursery trees being shipped to a job site or another retailer, etc.  Miri

goal: Find a safe and effective solution to control dusky birch sawflies on a young birch tree.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
We have a young birch whose foliage has been completely devoured by dusky birch sawflies.  I’m not familiar with any of the chemicals that are recommended to treat it.  Is there a reasonably safe solution we can treat the birch with next spring?

Thank you for your help.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Dione,  Thanks for reaching out to the UNH Extension Infoline. People often mistake sawfly larva for caterpillars, which they are not so the usual treatment of Bt spray (Bacillus thuringiensis) that is used for caterpillar control isn't effective.  Luckily, birch sawfly populations are inconsistent from year to year so even if they do significant damage one year, they likely won't be back the next.  Have a look at this article from UVM Extension- https://www.uvm.edu/news/extension/dusky-birch-sawflies Because of the low risk of plant mortality, we generally don't recommend chemical control for this insect pest. If they do return in the spring or summer, there are a couple of more natural ways to control that are proven to be effective. These are insecticidal soaps and horticultural oil sprays which should be used when the larva are still young and small.   I hope this helps and please ask if you have any further questions!

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Sean, Thanks for your reply.  I'll keep my fingers crossed that next year the sawflies won't be overwhelming, but I was hoping you could give me  information on the insecticidal soaps and horticultural oil sprays you mention.  Is there something I can mix up myself, or is there a specific brand or product you can recommend for the next time the young larvae are covering the tree?  Many thanks for your help.DioneOn Wed, Oct 9, 2024 at 12:01 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

missing: User's preference for DIY solutions or commercial products

goal: Identify the type of mites or issue affecting the houseplants to determine appropriate action.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: We have a store where we sell houseplants. Some of us think everything is infested with spider mites, some of us think they aren’t spider mites but might be predatory mites or just little spiders. Before we remove all stock and quarantine and treat for weeks on end I wanted to know how to positively ID what we have. I do see predatory mites are more pear shaped but if I don’t have both present how do I know?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Photos can help us diagnose the issue, if you're able to send any. Leaf damage is a giveaway for spider mites, since predatory mites would not be causing stippling feeding damage (nor would true spiders). Spider mite webbing hugs the plant (foliage, stems, buds) fairly tightly (it doesn't tend to span wide distances) while spider webbing is more open and all-encompassing. For spider mite webbing to be as prominent as spider webbing, usually there would have to be a very high mite population, and so foliage damage would be evident.  Miri

goal: Find USDA approved canning recipes for vegetables without sugar.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I have purchased the USDA Complete Guide to Home Canning. My family does not eat sugar. Is there a resource for USDA approved recipes that DO NOT use sugar? I have read that omitting sugar is not a safety issue but want verification.  Thanks

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Joanne, thatʼs a great question, and one that has a slightly different answer depending on what it is you are canning.  Jams and jellies: you will need to use low or no sugar pectins and follow the directions on the pectin boxes. Jams and jellies with standard pectin will not jell correctly without sugar, so itʼs not recommended to remove the sugar from those recipes. Pickled vegetables: You can remove the sugar from a recipe and have a safe pickle. That said, youʼll likely have better tasting pickles if you use one of the recipes with no sugar in them to begin with. Recipes with a small amount of sugar (tablespoons) will also taste fine if the sugar is removed, but "sweet" pickle recipes with no "sweet" in them might not taste as good. Low acid recipes that require pressure canning for safety can have sugar safely removed. If there are any specific recipes you are interested in (or concerned about) adapting to remove sugar, let me know and I can take a look. Otherwise, itʼs not generally difficult to adapt your canning to be sugar free. Sarah

goal: Successfully plant elderberry shrubs.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Was digging a hole for an elderberry shrub, and even after rain off and on all week, the soil was dry as dust.  Is there anything I can do to improve it and plant my shrub there?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Yes, this has been the common experience around the region, as the rainy week-plus we had didn't deposit all that much water. The drought from earlier in summer that affected much of the state is ongoing in many areas (see linked map, which is updated weekly).  Adding organic matter like compost is a good way to improve the moisture-holding capacity of the soil. A shovel-full, more or less, will probably suffice for the average shrub in terms of root ball size. Avoid over-amending as this can set the plant up for stress later as the roots expand out from the original planting hole, though you could still top-dress the soil surrounding the plant with about an inch of compost, plus a couple inches of an organic mulch (bark, wood chips, etc., that biodegrades) that will itself compost into more organic matter over time. This will keep the soil well-amended over the long term, as soil life works that layer into the root zone naturally.  After planting (even if there was no drought), monitor the plant for watering needs so it establishes well and maintains a vigorous root system. The linked page provides guidance for how to water and how to determine when watering is needed.  Miri

goal: Ensure proper care and management of trees, including addressing damage and transplanting a seedling.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Yesterday, I was removing a dead storm damaged branch.  I didn't realize that it was still attached to a very much alive 21/2 inch limb and a strip of bark came off with it.  The strip is one half inch by fourteen inches.  Do I need to prune this branch back to the next limb?  And while I have your attention, there is a Sycamore "seedling" about a foot and one half feet tall. I would like to transplant this.  When is the best time of year to do this?

Thank you,

Richard Hyams

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Richard, The stripped bark should cause little damage other than cosmetic. I would keep an eye on the spot until it ages and watch for insect damage.    As regards to the Sycamore seedling, now would be a great time to transplant it.  Fall is best because the roots will get well established through the winter. One caution: If we go back to dry weather don't forget to keep it watered even as the weather cools.    Thank you for the question and I hope you have a great fall and a healthy and happy holiday season.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you very much Dan.  I couldn't hope for a better answer! RichardOn Fri, Oct 4, 2024 at 10:38 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Richard,   Next spring will tell if there was any serious damage. If it leaves out, but then the leaves wilt and die, you will probably have to remove the damaged branch. Most likely, that won't happen and you won't have any problems.     In the future, with larger limbs, use the 'three cut' method where you make your first cut under the damaged branch an inch or two out from the trunk. This cut is only an inch or so deep, but then when you make your full cut out from there, if it tears the bark as it falls, the tear will stop at that first under cut. The third cut is at the branch collar and the tree will then heal itself.    Enjoy the season.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for the information.  Pruning is not my strong suit and I will take your advice. RichardOn Sat, Oct 5, 2024 at 11:50 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

goal: Determine whether termite treatment is necessary for the user's property.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Are termites an issue in My county? An exterminator is recommending a $3,600 plan for my residential property.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your question. There are two groups of termites that have been found in Minnesota:  eastern subterranean termites (Reticulitermes) and drywood termites (Kalotermitidae). While both types are relatively rare, that doesn’t mean that they won’t be present.  If found, they usually are eastern subterranean termites.  Reports exist that this group has been identified in southern parts of Minnesota including Goodhue County. See: https://www.orkin.com/locations/minnesota-mn/termites https://www.pestworld.org/pest-guide/termites/drywood-termites/ - :~:text=What Do Drywood Termites Look,color and have six legs. https://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/insect/indoor/flies/medium/subterranean-termites.html https://apps.extension.umn.edu/garden/diagnose/insect/indoor/beetles/small/termiteworker.html As you have discovered, termite treatment is not cheap. I have two suggestions: 1). If possible, try to get a picture of the presumed termite and send to us. We should be able to provide some form of identification. 2). Get assessments and estimates from two other exterminating services. As University of Minnesota Master Gardeners, we cannot make recommendations for commercial enterprises. However there are several businesses in your county so you should have no problem in obtaining additional estimates. Good luck!! Please get back to us with any additional, related questions.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Andi You have asked two separate questions that different experts handle- in future please separate out each question in its own entry.  I can answer your walnut tree question— bottom line is no, unless you can find a wood working Hobbyist who has a portable sawmill, two trees are typically not cost effective to take down for the wood. There are a lot of factors to consider. Value of the trees will depend on the species, size, and condition. The number of trees, ease of removal and access to a mill are also factors. Best bet is to contact a local logger. You can look in the yellow pages or search online   Taking down trees is the most dangerous function in the arborist and tree service repertoire. Be sure whoever is removing your trees has professional status and insurance coverage.  You can find certified arborists here— http://www.treesaregood.org You can find professional landscape companies here—.  http://plantmichigangreen.com/aws/MNLA/pt/sp/home_page ; There is an Urban Wood group who may have someone interested in buying the wood once the trees re down— https://urbanwoodnetwork.org/chapter/michigan-state-chapter/   For your second question about squirrels, would you please enter a new question for that, and include a picture of the siding and one of the whole house taken far enough back so the overhanging trees can be seen, too. To add pictures to your new question,  To add pictures, click the link in your email and go into your question on the website. Click the “Drop files here or choose them” below the response box to attach them.  You can upload .jpg, .png, .gif, .txt, or .pdf.  NOTE- each picture must be 8mb or less.

goal: Prune a leggy serviceberry tree (Amelanchier laevis) to achieve a bushier habit and a good canopy shape.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: It was planted 4 years ago and is now leggy. We think dormancy in winter is the proper time. But where on the branch do we cut? And how much can we take off? Can we just shape it to a good canopy? Or should we cut just after where the branch node splits into more branches? How many nodes back from the tip can we cut?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello:  I found this info from a master gardener site  "serviceberry can be pruned to induce its natural production of offshoots. However, without the cultivar name (there are approximately 8 varieties), it is difficult to determine how plentiful the production of shoots will be. Perhaps the nursery where you originally purchased the shrubs may be able to provide the cultivar name.   Pruning cuts trigger a physiological response in plant cells which affects bud dormancy and branching habits. It will take at least three years to get the plants to have a bushier habit. Before you begin, take a good look at the plant and select about one third of the branches, divided evenly all over the plant. Cut the chosen branches back by 1/4 to just above an outward facing bud. The following year you can then remove half the branches that were left the last time, and in the third year all the remaining branches can be tackled. The best time to prune is when the plant is fully dormant in late fall.   Some key points to keep in mind : use sharp appropriately-sized bypass pruners to prevent bruising. Make sure to sterilize pruners with each cut, apply water and fertilizer in spring, and regularly check your plant for insects and diseases, such as powdery mildew, so that these may be treated early...."    hope this helps

dialog_context.text: It's a Snowcloud. Amelanchier laevisDoes that help?Thanks for this help.  _______________    R. A. Burrell On Oct 5, 2024, at 12:44, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

goal: Successfully overwinter roses in Kentucky to prevent losing any bushes.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: What is the best way to over winter roses in Ky?

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: When do I cut them back , when is the last time to fertilize, do I cover them or let them as they are. Any general maintenance.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Jim, Roses are generally easy to overwinter. Stop fertilizing if you haven't already and normally you would stop by mid-summer unless you have a nutrient deficiency. Depending on the rose type you may not need to do anything. You should wait to cut back roses until leaf drop or in md to late winter and remove dead, diseased, damaged branches first. If your rose is planted in an open site that gets a lot of wind and is grafted, you can pile mulch over the graft to help stabilize it for the winter and fluctuating temperatures.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your question to Ask a Master Gardener Volunteer with eXtension.  Burnt out grasses have been a problem in Northeast Ohio especially if you have not been watering the lawn throughout the drought that we have been experiencing.   If the grasses are browned out and nothing is growing underneath, as you suggest, I would recommend removing all dead grasses and reseeding those areas.   This source talks about choosing the right turf grass for your area: https://erie.osu.edu/sites/erie/files/imce/Program_Pages/ANR/Choosing%20right%20turfgrass%20for%20Ohio%20lawn.pdf   This site has great information on the proper mowing of various grasses in Ohio: https://ohioline.osu.edu/factsheet/hyg-5816  Take a look at your Scott's 4 Step bag - it should give you information regarding the proper use and timing of application in regard to newly seeded lawn areas.  In regard to ridding your lawn of Bermuda grass, I have attached the following website which deals with that specific question.   https://www.peoplesdefender.com/2021/06/26/time-to-control-invasive-bermudagrass/  Best of luck to you as you ready your lawn for winter!

goal: Diagnose the cause of leaf loss and holes in the tree's leaves and determine appropriate treatment.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
I'm writing for some advice (and hopefully a diagnosis) of what is happening to this tree alongside the house.  It has been losing leaves this summer and seems to have attracted a pest or disease that has holes appearing in the remaining leaves.

My questions are:
1.	   What is causing this to happen?
2.	       What can we do to treat the problem?
3.	       Is it too late to begin trying to treat the problem?
4.	       Should we begin treatment now or wait until Spring?
5.	       Would you recommend some fertilizer stakes to be put in the ground this Fall?
We look forward to hearing from you and whatever assistance and advice you can provide.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi John and Julie, thanks for the question. A little more information would help in determining what is going on with the tree.  Unfortunately, I could not make a positive ID of the tree. If you could give some more info and a well-focused pictures a leaf front and back (preferably ones that show the full leaf outline).  Check the trunk and branches for any abnormalities.  Have you watered the tree regularly?  Have you had a recent soil test If not you can get one here: Home | MSU Soil Test. The tree does look sparce.  The holes are probably not severe enough to affect the trees health, but the leaf loss does indicate some sort of stress. If it is a disease problem, it would be a good idea remove and destroy the dropped leaves that could harbor the pathogen.  Any kind of treatment will most likely wait until spring.  Trees in stress due to extremes in weather (heavy rain, high temperatures) can also show leaf drop.  Many trees in West Michigan have been dropping leaves from the previous high temperatures and lack of rain, you still have time to fertilize but without a soil test it would only be a guess. Turnover on tests is usually pretty fast in the fall.  I look forward to your response.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks for your response and follow-up questions   It's my guess that the tree has not been watered regularly (limited largely to rainfall only).  I didn't see any abnormalities on the trunk or branches.  We have not had a soil test done, but the tree is planted near Lake Michigan and the soil around the house is quite sandy.  I've attached a couple photos of a leaf that I hope is helpful in your identification.   Look forward to hearing from you with any additional suggestions you may have for what we can do yet this season. goal: Diagnose and treat the issue affecting the weeping cherry tree.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Any idea what this is caused from and more importantly, how to treat it ? Its a weeping cherry in Ellicott City. thanks

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: The sticky amber-looking sap is called gummosis. Gummosis on these trees is a reaction to stress, or damage. Most often, it is due to bark damage of some sort, such as from weed whackers/mowers or from a boring insect (called peach tree borers) that can drill into these trees. The pushing of sap is an attempt to flush out the intruder. You can learn more about this and other issues these trees can have at our publication here:  https://extension.umd.edu/resource/ornamental-cherry-trees-identify-and-manage-problems/ Unfortunately, once borers are within a tree, there is not a lot that you can do, though you can often prolong its life by trying to keep the tree less stressed overall.  Do we see landscape fabric stretched over the root area, including on the big root off to the right? We'd remove/cut out all of that that you can.   With climate change, growing conditions have changed, and in the last couple of years, there have been prolonged high heat and serious drought conditions. Pull any weeds around the tree and give it a layer of mulch no deeper than 2 to 3 inches, kept pulled back from contract with the trunk. Offer it water when we don't get an inch of rain per week. Here is our watering information:  https://extension.umd.edu/resource/watering-trees-and-shrubs/  Ornamental cherry trees often start to decline after 20 years or so, but you can keep it as long as you like if it pleases you, especially with blooms in the spring and colorful fall leaves.  I had one that slowly declined for many years, losing limbs one by one. I allowed it to stay near my bird feeders, even after it died completely and have been amazed to watch how much wildlife, especially songbirds and woodpeckers have used it for food, shelter and nesting sites (within hollow branches).  Christine

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you Christine for sharing your knowledge and experience with this issue. Should we attempt to remove the sap or is it beneficial in its process ?  Your feedback is most appreciated!  Suzie

known.symptom: Sticky amber-looking sap (gummosis) on a weeping cherry tree
known.possible causes mentioned: Bark damage, boring insect (peach tree borers), climate stress

missing: Whether the user has observed any signs of insect infestation or bark damage

expected_output: Have you noticed any signs of insect infestation, such as holes in the bark, or any physical damage to the tree's bark?
title: Weeping Cherry issue

goal: Effectively manage and eliminate the aphid infestation and black sooty mold on crepe myrtles.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: My crepe myrtles have had what appears like aphids and a black coating on the leaves. The landscape rock underneath has also turned dark. This was the 3rd year with this issue. Neem oil has not helped. Any ideas what the issue may be?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Sherryll, What you are experiencing is black sooty mold. That is the black coating on the leaves, rocks, and anything else that is below the aphids. Black sooty mold is a fungus that colonizes the excrement (honeydew) of aphids. The mold itself is generally not considered damaging, though it can prevent the plant from photosynthesizing if it is covering most of the plant.  You can wash the black sooty mold off of the plant using a strong water spray. This works better if the sooty mold has only been there for a short while. The best long term control of the black sooty mold is controlling the aphids themselves. There are many natural enemies of aphids such as ladybugs and lacewings. If these are not controlling the aphids well enough, you will need to use an insecticide. Most insecticides will kill aphids quite easily. I would recommend using something with the active ingredients of pyrethrin or pyrethrum as these are organic and will break down quickly in the environment - not killing as many beneficial insects. Good luck! Robby

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Robby,Thank you so much for this information!  If we go the insecticide route, should that be done next summer when the bush gets new leaves?Sherryll Jones On Sep 30, 2024, at 9:14 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

known.issue: aphids and black sooty mold

missing: Timing for applying insecticide for effective aphid control

goal: Get hydrangea to bloom and store dahlia tubers correctly for next spring.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
What is the best fertilizer, approach to get flowers. Our plant is full and healthy, but no flowers. 
Thanks

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Ann  Thanks for reaching out to the UVM Extension Master Gardener Program Volunteers!  Some reasons for the lack of blooms on the Hydrangea:  - Improper pruning (Which includes “pruning” by deer. Deer love to graze on the leaves and tender tips),  - Cold damage which kills flower buds but not necessarily leaf buds, and - Over fertilizing (adding too much nitrogen) which provides for lush foliage but does not increasing flowering.  Since I don’t know the variety of hydrangea you’re growing, it could also be improper placement. Some varieties grow best in morning sun with afternoon shade.  Some varieties produce flowers on wood generated the previous season, so if you prune your shrub back in the spring- you'd get healthy leaf growth, but no flowers.  Some “newer” variety hydrangea, which came to market in the early 2000’s (example -"Endless Summer") were propagated to have the ability to bloom not just on the previous year’s wood, but also on new wood.  Hydrangeas that bloom on old wood and are affected by cold damage (spring frosts or freezes) may have killed any buds that were present. These shrubs lose the ability to tolerate frost once the plant breaks dormancy.  Remember not to overfertilize as this will promote gorgeous foliage at the expense of flowering.  Guide to pruning hydrangeas (with good photos) Pruning hydrangeas for best bloom | UMN Extension  I do hope this information has been helpful! And with a little assistance, next season your hydrangea should be in full bloom.

goal: Diagnose and treat the issues causing yellowing and spots on a 37-year-old spider plant.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi my spider plant is 37 years old but I had them outside last month and I added potting soil and water. They turned yellow and have weird spots on the leaves. Help! Many thks Judy

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Judy,  Usually, leaf spots on houseplants are minor and don't require treatment, but it would help us to make a diagnosis if we can see the symptoms. Are you able to send a few photos with your reply? (You can attach image files or paste images directly into the body of your reply. Please use files at least 1MB in size so we can enlarge them if needed.)  When you say you added potting soil, do you mean that extra potting soil was put on top of the container's existing soil, or that the plant was repotted by replacing the old potting soil? Old potting soil can gradually accumulate minerals from tap water and unused fertilizer nutrients, and over time this can stress roots. Because of this, and since old potting soil also tends to drain more poorly over time, when repotting a plant (even if it doesn't need a change in pot size), it's best to remove as much old potting soil as possible and replace it with fresh. How often to do this depends on a few factors, but generally, every year or two should be fine.  Leaf yellowing can indicate a few issues, including over-watering, under-watering, too much light, too little light (not as likely outside as compared to growing indoors), or a need for fertilizer. Was the plant fertilized this past summer? And is the soil being allowed to get fairly dry at least an inch down into the soil before the plant is watered again? If the soil is kept too damp, the roots might be suffocating (in a sense) and not working properly, which can lead to leaf yellowing and shedding.  Does the pot have drainage holes, and if so, is any saucer it's placed on emptied promptly after watering? If not, pooled water can seep back into the drain holes and keep the roots too wet.  These are some initial thoughts as to why symptoms often develop on houseplants (whether they're indoors year-round or outside for the summer), but with photos, we can try to narrow the diagnosis down.  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Here they are.ThanksJudyOn Fri, Sep 27, 2024, 10:15 AM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

Two native clematis occur in Minnesota.  Clematis virginiana (virgin's bower) is the most common.  Go here to learn about it:    https://www.minnesotawildflowers.info/flower/virgins-bower  We can't identify the clematis species by viewing the photos, so what you have might or might not be Clematis virginiana. Cultivated clematis sometimes self-seed and naturalize locally. dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hello- I plan to replace a small Japanese maple in my yard with a larger shade tree and would like to choose native. The site is in full sun and is west facing. Not a huge front yard- site is near the sidewalk and probably 30 feet from the house. Had planned for a red october glory maple, but I am reading that some think this plant is too prevalent already. What else will grow quickly, look nice in the front yard and provide native benefits?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: You have many great native trees to choose from.  Red Maples like are beautiful, and if that is your favorite, go for it. (There are other varieties of Acer rubrum other than  'October Glory' available too. ) Shade trees like oaks(think if you want to deal with acorns), maples and black gum (Nyssa Sylvatica) can become pretty large over time (offering nice shade), and they tend to live for a longer time than smaller native trees.   Some beautiful, smaller trees to consider which also have multiple season interest  are flowering crabapples and dogwoods (look for varieties bred with some disease resistance - these trees feed songbirds too), sweetbay magnolia, fringetree or serviceberry (but don't be surprised if they sometimes get minor leaf diseases so they might not look 'perfect'- which isn't to be expected from native plants).   The Maryland Dept. of Natural Resources has a program to encourage the planting of native trees that offers a $25 off coupon on certain trees from participating nurseries: https://dnr.maryland.gov/forests/pages/marylandersplanttrees/introduction.aspx and here is their list of recommended trees from which to choose: https://dnr.maryland.gov/forests/Pages/MarylandersPlantTrees/Recommended-Tree-List.aspx  Generally, you want to plan for the spacing- for instance, find the mature width (leafy canopy), and cut it in half for the distance it should be from your foundation. (You didn't mention how far the sidewalk is from the planting spot).Be aware of underground and overhead utilities too. Here is our page on planting trees:  https://extension.umd.edu/resource/planting-tree-or-shrub/ and keeping them watered when needed for the first couple of years of establishment is key to long-term success:  https://extension.umd.edu/resource/watering-trees-and-shrubs/   Christine

goal: Diagnose and address the cause of yellowing in an established boxwood hedge.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Hi,
We have an established 40 ft. boxwood hedge that is suddenly yellowing.  They looked great all summer but last week we noticed they were yellowing.  Any thoughts or suggestions?  We live in Franklin, MI.

Thanks, and GO Green!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: In the absence of any photographs, I can only offer the most likely reasons for you Boxwood plants turning yellow. Yellowing leaves do not necessarily signal that your shrub is dead. But they are concerning because they mar the appearance, at least temporarily, of a plant valued for the beauty of its delicate, leathery, rich green foliage.  The good news is that there is usually a way to fix the problem of boxwood turning yellow. Following are some of the reasons boxwoods turn yellow and suggestions for how to fix it. The fix is different for each, so it's important to detect the reason in your particular case. Once you have fixed the underlying problem that caused their foliage to yellow, then all you can do is wait for them to green up again.  Fungal DiseasesRoot rot and boxwood blight are fungal diseases that attack boxwood. Root rot is caused by fungal pathogens in the soil. As with all fungal problems, it is most prevalent where the soil is overly wet.  To avoid having your boxwoods turn yellow due to root rot (or to keep the problem from getting any worse), make sure: --- You don't overwater, and--- The soil drains well. Boxwoods often harbor boxwood blight when they are being grown at the nursery. When you bring your plants home, you can accidentally spread them by shearing your shrubs in wet weather. This transports the disease from plant to plant. When you shear boxwoods, frequently disinfect your shearing tools with a disinfectant such as bleach to prevent spreading the disease. Shear them only on dry days.  Winter DamageAlthough this is unlikely in our case because you mention that they looked great all summer, it is possible for boxwood leaves to turn a coppery or yellowish color during a Northern winter. This is caused by exposure to wind and sun, which dry the plant out at a time when, due to the frozen ground, water is not readily available to it.  To prevent this "winter burn," spray an anti-desiccant on your boxwood in late November and again in late January. Alternatively, wrap your boxwood in burlap. Salt Damage This condition is also unlikely, as you report that your plants looked great all summer and it is not yet winter. However, you do not mention exactly where your boxwoods are planted, so the following may be helpful information to not. If your boxwoods are planted along the road, they could suffer salt damage during the winter in the North. You'll notice yellowing leaves come spring. When the salt gets on the leaves, it can dry them out. The salt can also get into the soil, keeping your shrubs from absorbing water properly.  Covering your plants isn't sufficient in this case since you wouldn't be able to keep the salt from getting into the soil. The only fix here is to choose a different planting location for your boxwoods. Alternatively, grow salt-tolerant plants along the road.  Dog UrineAnother cause of boxwoods turning yellow is stray dogs urinating on them. This happens because urine contains excessively high concentrations of nitrogen. Use repellents to keep stray dogs out of your yard. PestsBoxwoods are attacked by pests such as leaf miners and scale. Serious infestations can result in boxwoods turning yellow. Faithfully inspect your plants for pests, particularly the undersides of the leaves. If you find any pest activity, the articles at the close of this response will provide information about what to so. TipPerform "the scrape test" to see if your boxwood is dead. With a sharp knife, scrape off a bit of the bark on one of the branches. If what you see underneath is yellowish-green, that branch is alive; if brown, it's dead. Repeat on all the branches with yellow leaves. Prune out the branches you've determined to be dead. If you've pruned out the vast majority of the branches, it's probably time to replace the plant. More Tips about Growing Health Boxwoods:Despite all the various factors that can cause your boxwood's leaves to turn yellow, boxwood is not an especially hard plant to grow. Nor is it high maintenance unless you will be trimming it in a hedge. Here are a few tips to follow to keep your boxwoods healthy: --- Boxwoods are best planted in full sun in the North, partial shade in the South.--- Give your shrub a loamy soil that drains well.--- Locate it where it will be sheltered from winds.--- Boxwood roots are shallow, which can expose them to excessive heat. Put a layer of organic garden mulch, 3 inches thick, around your plant to give it protection from the heat. Following are a few articles which may help you determine what to do:https://www.canr.msu.edu/news/browning-of-boxwood-is-it-boxwood-blighthttps://www.canr.msu.edu/news/boxwood_insect_pestshttps://www.canr.msu.edu/news/boxwood-blight-disease-identified-in-michiganhttps://www.canr.msu.edu/news/boxwood_leafminer_a_serious_pest_of_a_favorite_landscape_plant

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thanks for your interesting question.  I don't see the hydrangea in the picture, but like you, I'd be hesitant to remove it.  I have some that didn't bloom for 4 years and then they did.  Plus, it will survive in your shady garden.  I commend you for not wanting to use chemicals.  Except for the hydrangeas, I was able to locate a only couple variegated spring blooming azalea shrubs: Girard 'The Robe' Azalea, Silver Sword. I wonder if this is what you mentioned in your question.  If it blooms, I'd keep it.  This site discusses them  https://www.rhododendron.org/blog/?view=category&cat_id=6 Azaleas need protection from wind and they also need acidic soil.  There are many perennials which grow well in the shade: hellebores, hostas, ferns which could go around your hydrangea.  This site has shade perennials and shrubs to help you  https://gardening.org/shade-loving-perennials/  Are you planning on planting the new garden in the grassy spot that is visible in the picture?  The ground seems to be  higher than the sidewalk and driveway.  If so, the soil could be dug out or you could put rocks around the edges and build the garden up.  I think building up might be easier.  If you put cardboard over the grass and throw on leaves and manure and compost during the winter, by spring you should have a nice bed to plant.  The cardboard will stop weeds and may even deter the ivy.  This type of bed building is called lasagna planting.  This site explains it https://growingplaces.org/wp-content/uploads/Lasagna-Gardening.pdf  I'm sure you know that usually the taller plants go in the back of a garden or in the middle of a garden that you can view from different spots.  After you choose your shrub and perennials and probably a ground cover (ajuga?), put the pots on the soil and move them around like you'd move furniture inside to see what pleases you the most.    Since I am not a garden designer, I'm attaching this link that describes in detail how to create a shady garden. https://ngb.org/create-the-ultimate-shade-garden/  I hope this helps. Feel free to contact me with any other questions you have.  Sincerely,

goal: Propagate a new crabapple tree with similar fruit characteristics to an existing tree.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: My friend has a crabapple tree that is over 30 years old. It has very large fruits that are deep red inside and on the peel. I want to grow a tree just like it as we cannot identify the variety to buy one. Can I plant seeds from the fruit or how do I propegate a new tree from cuttings? Do I need rootstock? Where would I get that? Thank you!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Good question! A apple seed will not be true to the parent tree because of the pollinator tree is different. I don't believe you can propagate an apple tree from cuttings. To graft you will need root stock in order to clone a new tree. Just like you don't know the crab apple variety, you have no way of knowing the root stock. A different root stock could affect the size of the tree. However, if or when the existing tree sends up a sucker, shoot from the root, you could graft a scion (branch/twig) from the existing tree onto the sucker and you will have successfully cloned the tree. Good luck! Grafting is simple enough but takes some know how to master it. Paul -Tree Care Advisor volunteer

goal: Understand why imidacloprid is not working effectively for grub control and seek evidence for a potential dispute with manufacturers.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I am just calling about the grubs this year. Are they particularly bad? What would be the explanation for why the imidacloprid isn't working this year?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello,  Yes, grubs have been a significant issue in Southeast Michigan in 2024. These pests, which are the larval form of beetles, feed on the roots of turfgrass, causing extensive damage to lawns.  Regarding the ineffectiveness of imidacloprid this year, there could be several reasons:  Resistance Development: Over time, grubs can develop resistance to insecticides like imidacloprid, making them less effective. More information at this link:  EPA Finalizes Biological Evaluations Assessing Potential Effects of Three Neonicotinoid Pesticides on Endangered Species | US EPA  Application Timing: The insecticide may not be as effective if it is not applied at the right time. Grubs are most vulnerable when they are young and actively feeding near the soil surface.  Environmental Factors: Weather conditions, such as heavy rainfall or drought, can affect the efficacy of imidacloprid. For instance, excessive rain can wash away the insecticide before it has a chance to work. More information at this link:  EPA Finalizes Biological Evaluations Assessing Potential Effects of Three Neonicotinoid Pesticides on Endangered Species | US EPA  Soil Conditions: Soil type and moisture levels can influence how well the insecticide is absorbed and distributed in the soil. More information at this link:  EPA Finalizes Biological Evaluations Assessing Potential Effects of Three Neonicotinoid Pesticides on Endangered Species | US EPA  Michigan State University (MSU) provides detailed guidelines and updates on pest management, which might offer more specific insights into the current situation and alternative treatments. More information at this link (Latest update):  How to choose and when to apply grub control products for your lawn - Turf (msu.edu)  I hope this helps!

goal: Successfully plant two potted shrubs in the ground while managing a root weevil infestation.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi! Based on the leaf patterns, I have two potted shrubs with root weevils. I planned to get them in the ground this Fall and I wonder if I shouldn’t plant them or if it’s OK. Thanks for any insights!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: You are correct. Black Vine Weevils. The adults notch the leaves, the larvae feed on the roots. The following information is from The Missouri Botanical Garden. The black vine weevil, Otiorhynchus sulcatus, also known as the taxus weevil, feeds on a wide range of ornamental plants but is most destructive in its larval stage to yew, hemlock, rhododendron, and several other broad-leaved evergreens as well as to some greenhouse plants such as asters, cyclamens, and impatiens. As an adult, it has a wide host range to include both deciduous and herbaceous plants. It is the most devastating of the root weevils throughout the northern half of the U.S. and Canada. Symptoms and Diagnosis Adult black vine weevil injury on broad-leaved evergreens and other hosts consists of marginal notching of the leaves. To detect weevil infestations on yew, examine the center of the plant near the main stems for notched and cut-off leaves. This damage is the result of adults feeding at night. The adult is 3/8 to 1/2 inches long, shiny, black, female, and cannot fly. It feeds only at night, and when disturbed, drops to the ground where it is virtually undetectable due to its coloration. Adult feeding rarely causes serious plant injury, however, the characteristic notches provide evidence that the pest is present and action is necessary to mitigate damage by the larva of the next generation. The larva causes the most damage by feeding on the roots and girdling the lower stems, disrupting the flow of nutrients and water through the plant. Its feeding may result in the death of the plant. The larvae are legless, C-shaped, and white with reddish-brown heads. They may be found at a depth of from 3/4 to 16 inches in the soil around the roots. Pupation occurs in the soil near the surface. Pupae are white with very prominent legs and antennae. Life Cycle Partially grown larvae overwinter in the soil. Adults emerge from the soil in late spring and egg-laying begins one to two weeks later. The female lays up to 500 eggs in the soil near the base of the plant over a period of two to three weeks. Larval feeding takes place from midsummer, when the eggs hatch, continues into the fall, and then again in the spring. Occasionally adults overwinter, which complicates the life cycle because eggs are laid earlier. There is usually one generation per year. The most vulnerable stage is the adult. The larvae are much less vulnerable because they are protected by the soil. Integrated Pest Management Strategies 1. Nematodes can be applied as a soil drench to control larval stages of black vine weevil. Several species have been reported to be effective. The nematodes kill by entering the victim's body and reproducing. Two species are commercially available: Steinernema carpocapsae and Heterorhabditis heliothidis. H. heliothidis has been shown to be more effective against the early stages of the weevil at greater soil depths than S. carpocapsae. Nematodes can last three months in the soil, but soil temperature must be above 50 degrees F and the soil must be kept moist for nematode survival. Unfortunately, drenches are less effective under field conditions than in a greenhouse situation. Organic Strategies  Consult the Organic Materials Review Institute (OMRI™) for appropriate Neem products. Updated 7/2024

goal: Ensure the health and safety of the current and future tomato plants in the user's garden.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Today I went out to my garden to find my cherry and super sonic tomato plants "littered" with what looks like long dandruff.  Can you please look at the pictures and tell me what it is, and how to fight it?  thanks, Lance Stange

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Good morning Lance,  Thanks for the great pictures!  Your tomatoes are being attacked by aphids, probably the green peach aphid which absolutely loves tomatoes.  If left unchecked, they can do a number on your plants.  Not only will they suck nutrients out of the leaves, but they can also transmit viruses.  The white "dandruff" you are seeing is the nymphs.  Upon closer inspection, you can also see the adults.  Their green pear shaped bodies, are almost the same color as the tomato leaves.  Usually a strong blast of water will wash them away and disperse them.  You can also clip off badly infested leaves if that's easier.  Alternatively, you can spray with an insecticidal soap or Neem oil.  Both of these may require multiple applications.  Here's some additional information you might find helpful:  https://hortsense.cahnrs.wsu.edu/fact-sheet/tomato-aphids/  Good luck Lance,  Here's hoping you get a good crop of tomatoes!  Bill k

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: From the second set of photos I believe you are dealing with Tall Fescue (Schedonorus arundinaceus, also known as Lolium arundinacea or Festuca arundinaceae).  It is a clump growing grass that spreads by tillers and seed.  The best ways to eliminate the tall fescue from the lawn are mechanically (digging) or with non-selective herbicides (glyphosate) for bigger areas. goal: Replace the maple trees with smaller native trees that won't damage the sidewalk or foundation.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Even before the lanternflies moved in, my maple trees have been showing signs of crown decline. These were planted by the city in our yard as part of a new development. I'd like to replace them with serviceberry or another smaller native that won't be an issue with the sidewalk or foundation at full size. What do I need in terms of permits/process?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Good news on the spotted lanternfly: they are not hurting trees or plants other than grapes and black walnut seedlings. They will be a nuisance insect for a time but we expect their numbers will sharply decline as they have in the counties where they first arrived in large numbers.  The maple trees actually look o.k., especially for newly planted ones given the intense and prolonged heat and drought that we have experienced this year. Has anyone been watering them?  In terms of process or permits, you would have to contact your county government for that information, though we'd be surprised if they would be willing to replace them at this point.  If you do keep them, monitoring them and watering when needed is crucial for the entire 18-24 months of establishment. Here's our watering page: https://extension.umd.edu/resource/watering-trees-and-shrubs/ And they definitely need some mulch and perhaps soil removed. You should be able to see a widening or flare at the base of the tree before it goes into the ground.  A trunk that goes straight into the soil/mulch like a telephone pole is one that will eventually weaken over time.  More on mulching here:  https://extension.umd.edu/resource/mulching-trees-and-shrubs/   Christine

dialog_context.speaker: user

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Autumn Blaze maples are a cultivar of red maple and silver maple. they are propagated from cuttings. if you grew these trees from seed, they will likely not be Autumn Blaze trees.  That said, I can't really tell what is wrong with your tree. is it one of 5 that is affected or all 5?. It may be lack of water since we are now in a dry spell. Young trees need about 5 gallons of water per week for the first 2-3 years.  Have you fertilized around it? They don't need any fertilizer so if they are growing in a lawn that gets fertilized they could be burnt from too much nitrogen. It also looks like it could be mites, from the photo you sent. You could send a sample to the diagnostic lab for identification, Instructions are in the link below. I would call them to make Sure you  collect the sample correctly. https://pdc.umn.edu/ https://trees.umn.edu/autumn-blaze%C2%AE-freemans-maple-acer-x-freemanii-%E2%80%98jeffersred%E2%80%99

goal: Address yellowing leaves on tropical hibiscus and ensure healthy overwintering.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I have Yellow leaves  again! You all advised me earlier this summer to fertilize w Osmocate. I did and it improved! Yellowing stated again maybe a month ago so I fertilized again and yellowing continues. Help!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi,  Once the leaves turn yellow you can't reverse them back to green again. This is pretty normal for tropical hibiscus to shed leaves, especially towards the end of the growing season.  Do you overwinter these indoors or were you planning to? They will be shedding leaves once you move them inside too.  This time of year you don't need to fertilize them more. How much are you watering? With the cooler nights coming, be sure to check the soil moisture before watering to let them dry out some in between. How many hours of direct sun are they receiving? If they are getting too much shade that could be causing the leaf yellowing and dropping too.  in Frederick county, you will probably want to bring these inside in about a month. They can handle some cooler nights but probably won't be too happy when the night time temperatures start to be consecutively below 50 degrees. Let us know if you have further questions.  Emily

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks I will monitor watering! Would it be ok to prune them a bit now or should I wait until next spring? I do overwinter the inside my home.Sent from my iPad On Sep 23, 2024, at 11:38, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Sarah, thanks for the question.  Looking at the pictures, it really doesn't seem to be a fungal problem.  Most fungi are usually specific to a certain family of plants.  Although there are generalist diseases, in your case it appears that everything is affected.  Some post emergent broadleaf herbicides can persist in the soil for a while.  Mulches can be contaminated or toxic. Salt can be a problem by the street or driveway causing yellowing or burned leaf margins. Since this appears to be universal in your landscape and you feel confident in your watering and planting, a pH or nutrient issue could be to blame.  A soil test (Home | MSU Soil Test) could validate this. Take a look at the different sections that have the problem and try to determine what they may have in common.   Are there certain plants that are unaffected?  If so, what plants are affected and what is not?  Do any of the plants show abnormal growth?  What type of soil do you have (sand, clay, loam)? Did you amend the soil in any way?  I believe we can solve this mystery! I look forward to your response.

We did not amend the soil at all when moving in, and I know the previous owners chemically treated the lawn. We do not. I killed grass to make way for beds using newspaper and cardboard, covered in mulch. whatever is affecting plants is NOT affecting the azalea, roses, holly, lavender, heuchera, bluebells, phlox, or delphinium. Our soil is fairly sandy in general. goal: Diagnose and resolve the browning issue in arborvitae plants.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: We planted 16 arborvitae in June.  They’re turning brown which seems to have started with one plant and is spreading. It seems to now be starting on the inside of the adjacent plants but is sometimes is a patch near the edge.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello This is likely transplant shock. All trees and shrubs go through this upon transplanting because they must establish new roots. Plants this size will take 2-3 yers to establish.  Dig down 8-10 inches after you water to see if soil is moist. You want moist soil, not soggy and not dry. Water early in the day so foliage is dry by sunset if you use a sprinkler that wets the needles. It is best to use a soaker hose at the base around both sides of the hedge. A quick connect type makes it easy to leave the hose in place in between waterings. Water these shrubs at least once a week in clay or loamy soils, 2-3 times a week in sandy soils. Water until the ground freezes.  Next spring through fall water in the same way when no substantial rain is expected that week(3/4- 1 inch of rain). Again, keep the shrubs watered up to when the ground freezes next year.  All evergreens need to go into winter well hydrated, but not drowning. A layer of mulch 2-3 inches deep and not touching the trunks or lower foliage will help retain water, discourage weeds, and make it easier to mow around the hedge.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for all of this great info. My husband said when he waters he has been watering up and down the whole plant and that lots of little bugs (gnat size) fly out? Could we have an infestation of something? Thanks Sent from my iPhone  On Sep 20, 2024, at 11:03 AM, Ask Extension wrote:    ﻿

goal: To manage the health and maintenance of an Acer tataricum tree in a community garden, ensuring proper pruning and addressing potential pest issues.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Hi,

We have an approximately 25-year-old Acer tataricum in our ornamental community garden (picture 1) that has struggled the last few years. It did worse after the drought this summer. (We are now watering it regularly; kind of like closing the barn door after the horse has left.) We recently noticed webs (circled in red on pictures 2 & 3) on a few of the branches and suspect that they are an indication of spider mites. I tried to get pictures of what might be mites but the pictures were all too blurry to be helpful.  

We have read your article (https://extension.umd.edu/resource/spider-mites-trees-and-shrubs/). We are considering spraying them with a hose to wash them off or using predatory mites for management if in fact what we have are spider mites. A concern we have is that near the tree are five Buxus sinica (Franklin's Gem Boxwood) and if we use water we don't want the mites to end up infesting the boxwood. 

Do you have any recommendation about how we should proceed?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: The webbing pictured is not from spider mites, and there is no spider mite feeding damage (which would be quite prominent for that much webbing to be visible) on the foliage. Instead, the webbing is probably due to spiders, which are beneficial because they prey on insects, or due to caterpillars, but not a type of caterpillar that is a serious pest in need of treatment. (If it were one of those, their communal webbing is much more extensive, and defoliation around the webbing would be prominent, which it is not.)  The dieback in the first photo might be attributed to either drought stress (directly or indirectly as a result of a secondary infection like Botryosphaeria canker, which can take advantage of stressed plants) or from poor pruning cuts. We can't quite tell from the photo because of the distance and the foliage hiding some of the branch stubs, but since it looks like the tree canopy was previously trimmed (to accommodate the power lines?) in a way that reduced the length of some substantial branches, we think the cuts might not have been made in the right location, allowing dieback to progress down the branch. Proper pruning cuts are diagrammed on our Pruning Trees page, which includes a link to a handy video tutorial by Iowa State University. We mention this because, even though it's unrelated to the webbing, the dieback in the canopy is significant and appears to necessitate more pruning, so we wanted to make sure additional branch removal was done properly to protect the health of the tree. Once wood decay sets in, it can't be treated except to prune it out. If Botryosphaeria is a contributing factor for dieback, affected branches will need to be pruned out since they won't recover.  Catching up on watering is good (even if intervention is a bit late, you're still helping to ensure roots aren't dying), but use caution so it doesn't accidentally turn into over-watering, since that will cause similar symptoms to under-watering (wilting, leaf scorch, pre-autumn leaf shed, etc.). Feel the soil about six inches deep in the root area and water thoroughly once the soil becomes somewhat dry to the touch at that depth. (If damp at that depth when checked, watering is probably not needed yet.)  Boxwoods can get their own type of mite ("boxwood mites"), but while spider mites (like Two-spotted Spider Mites) are sometimes generalists, able to feed on a wide variety of plants, we usually don't see them on boxwood. The same environmental conditions promote outbreaks of both, though, so they can appear around the same time. Conditions tend to center around heat and drought. Some cultivars of boxwood are naturally more pest-resistant than others, and in our experience, 'Franklins' Gem' does not tend to develop heavy mite damage.  Miri

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi Miri,  Thank you for your prompt and thorough reply. I am so glad I contacted the Extension Service! I am very pleased to know that we don't have spider mites but instead have beneficial insects! Your comments regarding the dieback are very helpful. As a community garden we have volunteers (including me) who often have more enthusiasm than knowledge. Your pruning guidelines are helpful and we will follow them for pruning our other trees. Because of the current condition of the maple we will be paying a registered arborist to do the trimming in February and hope for the best.  Your caution about over watering is also helpful. My concern about a lack of past water could easily cause me to over water. I'll check the soil at 6 inches and proceed as you have suggested. With gratitude,Lowell

known.actions considered: spraying with hose, using predatory mites
known.concerns: potential infestation of nearby Buxus sinica
known.expert feedback: webbing not from spider mites, possible drought stress or poor pruning, watering guidelines provided

missing: Whether the user has already planned or scheduled professional pruning services

expected_output: Have you already planned or scheduled professional pruning services for the Acer tataricum, or are you considering having volunteers perform the pruning?

dialog_context.text: Hello,  I have prepared to seed a new lawn with long fescue. There was old grass which was roto tilled cleaned. Weed and feed applied in July. dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Jeanine,  Thanks for your question. Unfortunately, every time you till, you're disturbing the weed seed bank and seeds that were buried can come to the surface and germinate. And to clarify, there is nothing currently planted in the space, correct? It hasn't been seeded?  What are you planning to plant? And you still want to plant this fall?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Nancy;  I am having a bit of trouble suggesting an animal at this point. The smaller holes look more the size of a chipmunk or ground squirrel. The larger ones could be several holes that got washed out to look like a bigger one. Have you observed anything going in and out of them? Chipmunks would be active during the day but other animals would be more active at night. Check the area for footprints? As far as dealing with it, try filling the holes and watch for them to be dug up again to better understand if this is a long term issue. Consider also spraying some animal deterrent in the area, too, after you fill them in. Animals will often dig again when filled in with dirt but perhaps you can get a better track print or see them when they come back. I would also shine an outdoor light on the area for a while at night to make it less inviting. The more things you do at the same time, the more successful you may be. As far as getting rid of anything, you can work on preventing them from being too close by not using birdseed and making your landscape area less inviting (less open dirt areas). We cannot ever "get rid" of any small mammal but can do a few things to help them choose other settings.  Please feel free to contact me again if you want some additional follow-up.

goal: Effectively manage and reduce grub infestation in the lawn.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Can I apply Arena .25 now (September 17, 2024) to reduce grub infestation? Can I wait for rain to apply and let it wash it in? (Prefer to do this versus watering area myself).

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Good afternoon and thank you for your question.  Unfortunately, I cannot confirm from the photos alone that you are dealing with white grubs.  Can you please roll back the turf and provide a photo so I can get an idea of the white grub populations you are experiencing.    If it is grubs, it is likely too late to get this product down and taken up into the plant.  Because it is a systemic insecticide, it could take over two weeks to get taken up into the plant and be effective. Possibly even longer with the drought we have been experiencing and since the grass is not actively growing, the function of the phloem and xylem has slowed way down. Waiting for rain would even delay the process even further.  Typically at this time of year, we also also dealing with third instar larvae (the largest and final larval stage) present in the soil. It is recommended that the application is made prior to the third instar grub due to the fact that they stop feeding and descend into the soil as winter approaches.  This insecticide is much more effective when applied as a preventative verses a curative.   Once I see the photo, I can better guide you.  Thank you again for your question.  Jen

dialog_context.text: Not many but photo shows insect (is it a grub?) I have seen white larvae in the past.Thank you.Sean Griswold <personal data hidden> On Sep 18, 2024, at 1:58 PM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

goal: Identify the cause of distress in oak tree leaves and determine if any action is needed.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: We have oak trees which have leaves showing signs of distress. They mostly have brown fuzzy balls on the leaves, but a few also have yellow smooth lumps on them as well. Can you help us identify what is causing these?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi, These are great pictures of oak leaf galls. Could we use one for our October e-newsletter?  So a tiny wasp lays eggs in the spring on leaf buds and a chemical is injected into the leaf that causes an abnormal growth to occur and that is where the insect larvae is. So this causes a gall to form. The insect matures and eventually leaves (the wasps are very tiny). They really are just a cosmetic issue although they can make the leaves brown and fall a little earlier. We don't recommend any controls but if they are on a lower branch and you really don't like them you can cut them off.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your quick and reassuring response.  Of course you can use my photos.

known.impact: Cosmetic issue, may cause leaves to brown and fall earlier
known.recommendation: No controls recommended, optional pruning of lower branches

goal: Diagnose and resolve the issue causing the yellowing and spreading damage in the lawn.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: see attached photos.  7-24-24 photo was how small it started.  8-5-24 shows how much area has spread.  Began 3 consecutive treatments (2 weeks apart) of Scotts DiseaseEx™ Lawn Fungicide @ curative rate.  NO SLOWDOWN!  As seen in 3 photos taken today, 9-17-24.  The entire yellow area would not fit into the field of view in today's photo, 9-17-24.  It's now consumed the entire side lawn with small yellow dots spreading and each grows to join the large yellow blob that is constantly increasing in area.  I'm the homeowner type that is extremely fussy about the look of our lawn.  This has taken me to the limits of my patience.  We have irrigation, irregular watering schedule.  We've had so much rain earlier this year.  This area gets a fair amount of sun.  I do not bag my grass clippings.  I WILL GLADLY PAY SOMEONE GOOD U.S. $$$ TO COME TO MY HOME.  LUNCH INCLUDED!!!!  NEAR 494 AND HWY. 62 IN MINNETONKA/HOPKINS AREA.  PLEASE HELP!!!!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Good Morning John,  Thank you for contacting the U of M Extension Service. You indicated you applied a fungicide treatment. How did you determine it is a fungus?  You might inspect the soil below the spots to see if this issue is grubs: https://extension.umn.edu/news/white-grub-control-lawns Here is a link to the lawn care calendar: https://extension.umn.edu/planting-and-growing-guides/lawn-care-calendar You could also send a sample to the Plant Disease Clinic to verify the probem: https://pdc.umn.edu/ I would pull up the sod in an area where the grass has died and see what is happening to the roots and the soil. Might inspect for grub damage.  I would also closely examine the dying grass blades to see what other issues might be apparent.  Is the soil compacted or is there any other issues that may have caused the probem?  I will also mention the newer alternatives to lawn turf grass. Turf grass is a sterile environment for nature. Various chemicals applied to the turf grass makes it additionally toxic to our pollinators.
