goal: Identify and treat issues affecting azaleas and milkweed plants.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
I have two problems.  One concerns my azaleas (2 next to each other) and the other my milkweed. Can you please help me identify the problems and provide treatment ideas?

Thanks.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: The azalea foliage symptoms look like mild lace bug damage (a very common pest on azaleas, especially if the plants are growing in lots of direct sun, which stresses them). There is also a small amount of leaf darkening or reddening that can also be attributed to environmental stress, possibly from drought or high heat. (Leaf reddening during winter is also normal for many azalea varieties, and it's due to similar conditions -- stress from temperature or inaccessible soil moisture -- during that time of year.) A location next to a wall can compound summer stress by reducing air circulation, reflecting extra light, and contributing to heat build-up and soil drying.  No management for lace bug needs to be done now, and you can monitor the plant for a new generation of lace bugs next spring. If you intervene, options are included in the page linked above, though usually only a strong spray of plain water from a garden hose or a few treatments of horticultural oil or insecticidal soap are needed to suppress their numbers. Either method must contact the leaf undersides to be effective, as that is where lace bugs will be living and laying their eggs.  Were the azaleas monitored for watering needs this summer? If not, start checking them periodically and watering as needed (once the soil becomes somewhat dry to the touch around five inches down) so they can maintain healthy roots and not lose flower buds that have formed for next spring's bloom.  The milkweed discoloration is hard to diagnose, but it does not appear to be due to disease or any pest activity; it too looks like a result of environmental stress. No action needs to be taken, and if nothing else is going on unrelated to the leaf symptoms, then the plant should go dormant as usual later this autumn and regrow normally next year. Is this a Swamp Milkweed? (It looks like it is.) If so, it is growing in moist soil? If also affected by drought, the plant's roots would fare better if periodically watered during dry spells. Cecil County, like much of Maryland, experienced notable drought for at least part of this past year, and is currently abnormally dry again.  Miri

dialog_context.text: Thank you for the quick response.  We will monitor watering needs better.  I was curious about the white fuzzy growth on the ends of two branches?  There are about 15 on the plant.  Should I cut them off?   Thanks again, Shirley

goal: Determine the cause of the plant die-off and decide whether to replant the same species or make site adjustments.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I used to have two rows of them going down the slope where my flagstone steps are on the south side of my house.  They've done well for 20 years.  It gets full sun.  But this summer half of one of the rows the plants turned brown and died.  Don't know if my lawn guys maybe put a bit too much mulch around them, or whether it was the extreme heat we got.  I've trimmed them only minimally over the years (should I trim more to salvage the remaining ones?).  Should I replace them with the same thing?  Do I need to adjust the soil?  Do I need to fertilize them if I do that?  And same for the surviving ones, to keep them from going brown and dying?  Any suggestions would be most appreciated.  I sent two photos to Kaitlyn Baligush but they would not attach here.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: We have asked Kaitlyn to send us the photos you shared with her, though if the attach-file function is not cooperating on your end, you could also paste images directly into the body of your reply instead. (Please make sure they're at least 1MB in size so we can enlarge them.) Until we receive them, we'll make a couple educated guesses as to a diagnosis.  Too heavy of a mulching can interfere with root health as well as harbor certain pests (in this case, mainly voles that might have chewed into the base of the main stem(s)). A mulch layer should be no more than 3 inches thick over a plant's root zone, and not piled against its main stems or base. Our primary suspect in this case, though, is moisture-related...were the junipers being monitored for watering needs during this year's drought (which is still present in parts of the state, including most of Montgomery County)? Even though junipers are known for their good tolerance to drought, it is just that -- a tolerance, not a preference -- and they can be pushed over their limits and succumb to damage if the roots get too dry. The drainage or moisture retention between the two planting sites, despite how close to each other they are, could still differ and result in different rates of drying out for each planting. Is either location in competition with any nearby tree roots, even if the shade from that tree isn't overshadowing the junipers?  Fertilizer does not benefit stressed plants, and may actually make the situation worse if a nutrient deficiency in the soil is not the sole reason for plant damage. (It would not be here, given the symptoms you describe.) Established shrubs, junipers included, should also not need routine fertilization.  Junipers should not need regular pruning, though they will tolerate a bit if it's needed to remove errant growth or restrain size a bit (drastic pruning to restrain size is not as well-tolerated and can lead to dieback in certain circumstances). For plants with brown branches, those stems will not recover and will need to be pruned off back to where they join still-living wood. Healthy growth should not need trimming, and any plant wound (even from sharp pruners) does run a risk of becoming infected or colonized by wood decay organisms, so each pruning cut on a shrub or tree should be made with good reason. For junipers with too much brown growth (dieback), or if any plants turned entirely brown, they will need to be removed/replaced instead since they cannot recover. You can replace them with the same variety if you prefer a symmetrical look, and if the site doesn't have conditions (like too much shade or poor drainage) that conflicts with the needs of the juniper. For example, if drought was the primary cause of their demise (our working theory so far), then replanting should be fine.  Miri

It's hard to see enough detail in the close-up photo as it appears to be out of focus or lower in resolution, but for the other image, site conditions does appear to be the primary factor involved. (Heat reflecting/radiating off the wall and the wall also limiting airflow, plus the slope's drainage potentially drying out that area more quickly (though not all slopes drain very well).) The mulch doesn't appear to be laid too thickly, though it's hard to tell. Soaker hoses can be a great way to water while conserving moisture, but check on them once in a while to make sure they're still functioning normally along their entire length, since sometimes (in a drought especially), thirsty wildlife (rodents or rabbits, mostly) might find them and chew into them, making them leak.  Miri

dialog_context.text: Have tried removing the white spotted leaves but that is almost all of the leaves.  And it doesn't keep it from forming on the leaves left.  Do I need to remove the plants and their mulch and start over with new soil and plants?  Or could I do this in spring when the Blanket Flowers start to emerge so I can remove them carefullly and then put the same ones back in the ground?  They get nice flowers that the bees love.  The beds are only about 3' x 3' , one on each side of my back door porch steps.  Any advice appreciated.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi- how spaced out are your plants? Is there decent airflow?

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your quick response!  There is nothing not one plant in each bd space but I have been putting annuals in there, too. Sent from my iPhone On Sep 16, 2024, at 10:05 PM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I'm going to resend my earlier answer with mistakes corrected, and my apology.  My cell phone likes to autocorrect to different words.  Here's what I intended to send you, and, I will incude a picture this time.    Thank you for your quick response earlier today! There is only one plant in each bed space but I have been planting annuals in the space, too.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thank you for the picture! Unfortunately, powdery mildew spores could come from miles away, but airflow is a very common reason it would spread, which is why I asked that first. If everything infected isn't removed right away, it's likely to stick around and reinfect the plant again later. The mulch should probably be removed, as it could be infected. This plant likes dry, well-draining soil, and full sun. How often and when are you watering it?   There are a few methods that may work, alone or in combination- cutting it down to 6 inches and removing any mildew in the fall,- this would be my first choice, along with new mulch, not too close to this plant,  -or: planting something not prone to powdery mildew in that place next year, depending on the variety of blanket flower you could collect it's seeds, or only keeping the best portion of your plant for one bed. Fungicides or horticulture oils are options, last ditch efforts, if you were open to them, in an attempt to prevent it next year.   Some resources: https://extension.umn.edu/plant-diseases/powdery-mildew-flower-garden   https://hort.extension.wisc.edu/articles/blanket-flower-gaillardia-spp/    https://ipm.ucanr.edu/home-and-landscape/powdery-mildew-on-ornamentals/pest-notes/#gsc.tab=0

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for the advice and prompt response!  After reading it I believe I will move the two plants this fall.  One last question: Should I do this after first cutting them to six inches and removing all of their leaves and shaking soil off of their roots? I will move them to another drier, sunnier location for a better life for them.   On Tue, Sep 17, 2024 at 8:40 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

missing: User's approach to handling the plants during the move, especially regarding cutting and leaf removal

expected_output: When you move the plants, do you plan to cut them back or remove any leaves to help manage the mildew?
title: powdery mildew recurring on Blanket Flowers x 3 years

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello, It looks like you had decent control, but I have seen better. Did you add a methylated seed oil (MSO) to your spray solution?   How do you plan on doing the seed establishment? Aerification, slit seeder, tilling, raking etc??? But, yes seed will germinate as long as seed-to-soil contact is good. It is best to eliminate any weed competition prior to establishment as this will produce best results.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thanks for your response.  I used baby shampoo as my surfactant.  After most of the crabgrass and many other weeds died, I did power raking to scrap the soil and remove some of the dead weeds. I can now see the soil.  I realize the power raking could increase crabgrass seed deposits, but in some areas, I couldn’t see the top of the soil.  Can’t see seeds germinating through that dead weed vegetation.  There are still weeds that appear to be alive.I did a soil test and found neutral ph, but depleted nitrogen, potash and potassium.  My plan is to apply starter fertilizer, water it in and use some top soil as a top dressing, then over seed, but would love any advice you can offer..  Sent from my iPhone On Sep 16, 2024, at 11:29 AM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.text: Thanks for your question and pictures.  My initial response to the soil report is that I don’t see anything of significance that might be responsible for the appearance of the gold mound spireas.  Yes there is a high level of phosphorus, but this rarely has a detrimental effect upon plants. Moreover, phosphorous levels are notoriously variable and subject to rapid fluctuations, sometimes on a weekly level.  I think we have to consider other possibilities. To assist me in my thinking, I need answers to the following: 1).  You said that the soil report was from the gold mound area. Does this mean you also have a soil report for around the gold flame and just didn’t send it to us?  Or, does it simply that you only took a soil sample from around the gold mound spirea? 2).  What is under the rock mulch?  Specifically, is there any type of plastic covering or landscape fabric?   3).  You indicated that these spireas were planted in May 2022.  Does this mean that this whole garden area, including the mulch, were also established in May 2022?  Or had this area and mulch existed prior to May 2022 but other things were planted there?  if the latter, what was planted there and how did it grow? 4).  I’m curious about the drainage around the garden. Does water from the sidewalk and adjacent driveway drain into the gold mound area?  Were any deicing compounds used on the sidewalk and/or driveway during the winters of 2022/23 and 2023/24?  Related to this, when snow is shoveled in the winter, does more snow end up the gold mound area than in the gold flame area? 5).  Does the discharge  from the downspout largely flow onto the gold mound spirea? At this time l’m inclined towards thinking that we are looking at some environmental cause rather than a soil problem. I’ll look forward to your responses and additional thoughts. Thanks for consulting our forum.

goal: Ensure the safety and quality of canned plums.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I canned yesterday. Some of my jars have small bubbles. Can I store them?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Sam,  Small bubbles often form in canned fruits when air is driven out of the fruit during canning and forms bubbles in the syrup. The only situation that might be concerning is if, after a few days of sitting on the shelf, the syrup started actively creating new bubbles. That would be a sign of fermentation in the fruit. Best practice is always to "debubble" your jars before affixing the lid. You can do this by running a plastic knife or chop stick around the inside of the jar, slightly nudging the fruit to release trapped air bubbles. This helps reduce the number of bubbles in the final jar and ensures proper headspace. Hot packing your fruit, by briefly simmering it in syrup before packing it in jars, also helps to drive air out of the fruit tissues before canning.  In short, no safety concerns with small bubble in your cans of plums aa day after canning. If you see active bubbling after a day or two more, then you might have fermentation going on and need to dispose of the product. Thanks for reaching out with your question! Jared

goal: Safely eliminate a hornets' nest to protect dogs and humans.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
I'd like to find out how to get rid of this hornets' nest.  As you can see from the pictures it's under the roof of our dog runs.  It has clearly been there quite a while but has not been a problem till yesterday and we didn't know it was there till then.  But yesterday one of our dogs was stung once and when I went to find out what was going on I saw a large number of hornets, gotstung myself, and saw that both dogs were being stung.
We kennel our three dogs at least once every week or so meaning I need to be rid of this thing soon.  Having the hornets just leave would be ok as well as just destroying it/them. 
If I've not identified the insects correctly please correct that.
Pictures attached.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: I am so sorry to hear about your dog. Yes, these nests can build for month before they are noticed.   A few things about yellowjacket biology may be useful here (and yes, the black and white bald-faced "hornets" are just another species of yellowjacket). First, the nests are not perennial, they are annual. In fact, the nest is now reaching its peak population and should begin crashing within a month. The colony should be completely dead by November.   If you cannot avoid the nest until it collapses you will need to kill the nest. Given its height, I would recommend bringing in a pest control professional. To do it yourself would involve climbing a ladder and spraying an insecticide formulated for yellowjacket control into the entrance of the colony (which is the hole at the bottom of the nest). There is a risk that the yellowjackets could fly out at you while on the ladder, causing you to loose balance and fall.   There is a great (out of print) University of Idaho Extension document that goes over your options. You can download it here: https://beav.es/pRT

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Dr., Thank you very much for your comments and the link to a fascinating paper from Idaho.  I have a cannister, Spectracide PRO, wasp and hornet killer.  Its active ingredients are .10% tetramethrin; .25% permethrin; and .50% piperonyl butoxide.  It asserts that it has a 20 ft spray reach. We need to use the dog runs, as soon as the end of this week, so I can't wait. My plan is to wait till late twilight or full nightfall and from a reasonable distance spray the entrance of the nest and then the entire nest till it appears wet.   Will the darkness provide me any protection from the hornets? Will one treatment likely be enough? Again, thank you very much for the help. Bill

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Bill,   I know, isn't the Idaho publication great?  In my experience an application of a pyrethroid-based insecticide like the one you list should work with a single application. Read the instructions on the label carefully. I am looking at an example of this product label (which may differ from the one you have) and it does warn not being directly under the nest, as you will be dispensing a large volume that could potentially drip back on you. Also note the label specifies watching the wind conditions (although in the enclosed space, the risk of wind may be minimal) as it could cause the spray to drift back onto you. Applying at sunset is recommended on the label and the wasps will be less active (but not totally inactive). Make sure to have a plan to get into cover if the wasps to fly off the nest (i.e., think about where you will go if there are wasps flying around, ideally through a door you can close or into dense shrubbery). It would be prudent as well to let someone else in the household know when you are making the application who you can check-in with. Finally, when done with the application, check the directions on how to dispose of the product after use.   Good luck out there.

goal: Determine if soil replacement is necessary before replanting apple trees to prevent future disease.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hello.  I have two espaliered apple trees, growing alongside my house, with very sturdy trellises.  The two are about 20 years old.  They have grown happily and healthily until about two years ago, when one became ill.  We had Bartlett Tree Experts look at it, and they declared apple blight, and applied a treatment.  Things continued to go downhill, with one tree dying completely and the other ailing.  Bartlett looked again and said the problem was inadequate watering.  So we stepped up watering to their recommendations (though we were a bit suspicious of this diagnosis since we have been watering steadily, and had no issues for the first 18 years or so).  This did not work and now we have two dead trees.  We can ask Bartlett for a post-mortem, but given their track record, would like a second opinion.  Which leads to my question, assuming we dig up and replace the trees.  Do we need to REPLACE the soil?  Given we don't know exactly what killed the trees, is there any illness they could have had which leaves bacteria or whatever in the soil, such that replacement seedlings would also die, and soon?  In which case, we would not just plant new trees, but remove X cubic yards of soil and replace it, first.  Thank you very much!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Greetings, Glenn, and thank you for your question to AskExtension/Ask a Master Gardener. You must be heartbroken over the loss of your espaliered apple trees. I am guessing they were magnificent. (I would love to see a picture of them in their prime!) I cannot definitively diagnose the issue with your trees, and therefore can’t determine whether or not soil replacement is recommended, but I can give you some information, guidance and suggestions that will hopefully help you decide on the best course.  You wrote that the company initially diagnosed “apple blight”. I have not been able to locate any information about "apple blight" in research-based publications, but I can make an educated guess that they were referring to “Fire Blight” (FB), a bacterial disease that attacks apple, pear and other plants in the Rosaceae family, and which is common in Ohio. Once a tree is infected with FB, it is very difficult to successfully treat. This article from Ohio State’s Ohioline and this article from Penn State Extension will give you more information. Trees with FB often exhibit a tell-tale “shepherd’s crook” on new growth, which may help in diagnosis. The bacteria do not live freely in soil, so if all branches, leaves and cankers were removed before replanting, new trees would not be infected from the soil. (See here.) However, if there are other nearby plants that have the FB bacteria, it could be spread to replacement trees by wind, insects or pruning. A recommendation would be to choose apple trees resistant to the Fire Blight bacteria. The Ohioline article referenced above has a list of resistant rootstocks and tree varieties. Another possibility is that they meant Botrytis blight, which is a fungal infection that affects many plants, including apple trees. It is less lethal to trees than FB (1.5/5.0), but the fungus can remain in the soil for about three years. Soil can be treated with fungicides, although that can have a detrimental effect on soil health, as beneficial fungi will also be destroyed.  Recommendations:  - If the trees have not yet been removed, my recommendation would be to send a sample to the PPDC (Plant and Pest Diagnostic Clinic) at The Ohio State University. You may submit either physical or photographic samples, but in your case a physical specimen would be best. There is a small fee of about $20. (Please note that we do not receive any proceeds from recommending this service.) Directions for submitting a sample can be found here. If they can make a definite diagnosis, you will have better information for preparation of your soil. - It might also help you to have a professional soil sample analysis. It will give you excellent information moving forward. You can find all you need to know here. - Choose replacement trees resistant to Fire Blight, as noted above.   In preparing a response to your question, I referred to research-based sites to ensure that my response was accurate and timely. If you are interested in learning more about this topic, the best of those sites are embedded in the text and/or listed below. Wishing you the very best in replanting your beloved espaliered apple trees! (I am assuming you plan to espalier the replacements?) If you need any clarification, or if you have further questions on this topic, please feel free to contact me; if you reply to this email, it will come directly to me. I would love to hear from you! Best Wishes, Debra Simson, Master Gardener Volunteer ------------------------------- Resources for you: Fire Blight of Apples and Pears – The Ohio State University Ohioline https://ohioline.osu.edu/factsheet/plpath-fru-22-0 Fire Blight – AZ Cooperative Extension https://repository.arizona.edu/bitstream/handle/10150/144803/az1030-2011.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y  Fire Blight in Ornamentals - Penn State Extension “The bacterium overwinters on infected plants in darkened, slightly sunken cankers. In the spring, the bacteria are dispersed by insects, rain, wind, and animals. The bacteria build up on the plant hairs, stigmas, and other flower parts. Note that the bacteria do not survive free in the soil.” https://extension.psu.edu/fire-blight-in-ornamentals#:~:text=The%20bacterium%20overwinters%20on%20infected,survive%20free%20in%20the%20soil.  Fungal Disease – Gray Mold University of Illinois Extension https://web.extension.illinois.edu/hortanswers/detailProblem.cfm?PathogenID=33 Botrytis Blight in Apple Trees – University of Kentucky Extension https://plantpathology.ca.uky.edu/files/ppfs-gen-19.pdf PDDC – Submit a Sample – The Ohio State University CFAES https://ppdc.osu.edu/submit-sample  Soil Testing for Ohio Lawns, Landscapes, Fruit Crops and Vegetable Gardens - The Ohio State University CFAES https://ohioline.osu.edu/factsheet/hyg-1132

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Mike,  It looks like you might have animal browsing pressure - and this looks like it could be squirrel damage or another mammal. You might have to resort to the techniques that they use up in Estes or other areas by using fencing/caging around the plants.  You can try to clean up the torn areas by cutting away the loose shards (do not cut into the branch or new tissues). Some of the branches may not survive because of the extensive damage.  Going forward, focus efforts on regular watering, including in fall and winter. This will help the trees seal off the wounds and recover better - and support overall growth. Keep grass/weeds clear at the base of the trees and add mulch, if possible. Keep the mulch away from the trunk.   Also, can the ponderosa support itself without the stake? The green tape is flexible but can cut into the trunk and cause a constriction, which affects the flow of water and nutrients. If possible, remove the green tape and the stake.

goal: Manage and prevent the spread of invasive Asian Jumping Worms in a garden in Denver.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi! I am a garden designer in Denver and have a client with a unique problem. We have been planting and adding to their garden for a few years now and have noticed plants declining and dying without explanation. I have done a soil analysis through the extension and all conditions seem to be excellent for planting. However, we discovered that most areas of the garden are riddled with hundreds of worms, which very much look like invasive Asian Jumping worms. The first 2 inches of soil are nothing but worm castings. I have attached a picture here for ID. Thanks for any help.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Russell, I agree that it's an Asian Jumping Worm (based on the location and color of the clitellum). Unfortunately, there are currently no viable jumping earthworm control methods (but research is ongoing). Management hinges upon stopping their spread, and there are some methods that can be somewhat effective. Now that your area is known to be infested, avoid moving soil/plants from there to other areas. Tools/boots/tires used in that area should have all the soil removed from them before being used in new areas. Hand-pickingCollecting and killing the worms on sight is an option, albeit labor-intensive. Worms that are caught can be left in the sun for several hours to kill them. Once dead, the worms can be disposed of without fear of spreading them to new areas.  To make hand-picking easier, use a mustard pour (which is totally harmless to plants). Mix a gallon of water with 1/3 cup of ground yellow mustard seed and pour slowly into the soil. This will drive any worms to the surface where you can easily remove them.Soil SolarizationUsing a clear plastic tarp, completely envelop soil and leave it in the sun so the mass reaches at least 104°F for at least three days Let me know if you have further questions.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for the ID and the information regarding management. I haven't heard of these being an issue in Colorado yet- I am a little concerned since the worms have seemingly infested the entire property. We are worried that this will spread to neighboring properties and eventually will become a larger issue than one backyard. If there is anything that we need to do to avoid larger environmental impacts, please let me know. Thank you. On Wed, Sep 11, 2024 at 1:39 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

goal: Revive or replace mature lilac bushes that appear to be dying.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi, my name is Judith. I live in Marlborough, New Hampshire. My question is I have a number of very mature lilac bushes which have suddenly appeared to be dying. They are all. The leaves have fallen off and they look pretty dead. I wonder if there is anyone who could could help me. Please call me back.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Judith,Thank you for contacting the UNH Extension Infoline. This has unfortunately been a hot topic here at the Infoline over the last two weeks. It is difficult to clearly identify the sole problem but based on how some of the leaves appear to have brown spots it is possible that the lilacs have Lilac Bacterial Blight. This is a useful resource for this: http://plantclinic.cornell.edu/factsheets/lilacbacterialblight.pdf Make sure that if you fertilize your lilacs, don’t overfertilize and stop fertilizing all together around mid-summer because elevated levels of nitrogen in the soil can lead to more favorable conditions for the disease. We recommend testing the soil to check the pH and nutrient balance. The UNH Extension also has these services for $20 per test and you can find the form here.  Infected branches should be pruned 10-12 inches below the visible infection as soon as you see indications of disease. Pruning should be done during dry weather to minimize the chance of spreading the pathogen and if you are pruning your bushes late in the summer, make as few cuts as possible. The act of pruning sends a signal to the plant to grow and at this time of the year that can lead winter damage on tender new shoots. Pruned branches should be destroyed, ideally by burning. Always sterilize pruning tools between cuts to prevent spreading the bacterium to other areas on the tree.  You could also submit a sample to the UNH Extension Plant Diagnostic Lab for $20 to get a more definitive determination of the issue and ways to treat it. The submission form with directions is found here. Good luck with your lilac! Please reach out if you have any other questions and have a great rest of your week!

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi,This is Judith.  I’m afraid I have no leaves or branches that are living to send in.  About 8 bushes, some of them 30 to 40 years old, have no sign of life.I’m not sure when it happened, but definitely earlier this summer.  We were busy with my husband who was ill, and were paying no attention to the lilacs.They bloomed as usual this spring, although now that I remember, some branches looked dead.  Plants nearby, my roses, were eaten    down to shredded canes by rabbits, but have come back beautifully.I’m at a loss.  Do you have the name of anyone we could pay to come by and help us figure out what to do?Thanks for any help you can give.Judi de ForestSent from my iPhone On Sep 10, 2024, at 12:26 PM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

goal: Prevent deer from destroying garden plants, particularly hostas.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: This year my hostas looked terrific until the deer ate each plant to the ground. What can I do to control deers from destroying my hosts?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Reply sent 9/5/2024  Hosta are deer candy and in a deer infested area will always be eaten to the ground without protection. Given that you probably don't want to fence in your hosta and really want to keep them, the consistent use of repellants is probably your best option. I have attached a publication from Cornell listing some of the best options for repellants. Highlighted area. Please keep in mind that you need to alternate them as deer get used to pretty much anything after 4 weeks.  I have also used human hair from my hairdresser & dog hair spread over the mulch which has kept the deer, rabbits and ground hog out of my garden.  I found a strong scented deodorant soap, such as Irish Spring, in a net bag hanging about 24-30" off the ground on a plant stake also worked. Although you have to move the stake around periodically. 24-30" is their browsing and sniffing zone. These 2 ideas work best in conjunction with a repellant.  Your hosta should come back as long as they haven't eaten below the ground into the crown. For now, to prevent them from eating more of the crown, you can place a piece of chicken wire and mulch over the plant. As long as this drought weather persists they are going to eat the most succulent growth they can find, hosta fit that category.  If you decide to give up on hosta and the deer munching, contact our Sussex County helpline<personal data hidden>) and we can steer you towards less deer friendly landscaping plants.

goal: Effectively manage and mitigate the impact of a jumping worm infestation in the garden.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Hi -
I have a jumping worm infestation.  I'm currently pulling them out of the garden, but need to talk to someone about this HORRENDOUS problem.

I have info/ideas from the Extension website and PDF on the worms, and I really need some real world advice on next steps. I left a voicemail also.  I'm not attaching pics at the moment, they are in my yard:  granulated soil, dyeing flowers, huge nasty jumping worms along the surface, with the ring.
Thanks for your time!

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: I’m sorry to hear that you have jumping worms. They are awful!  Yes, they live in the top layer of the soil just under the leaf litter, unlike regular earthworms that live deeper in the soil. Be sure to report your infestation to the DNR if you haven't already done so. You have looked at our website and this is where you will find any new information as research progresses. Be sure to check the link for managing your emotions because this issue does produce heightened emotions. They are awful! You can Solarize your leaf litter to kill any adults and eggs living there. Do not compost at home as your small pile will not get hot enough to kill the eggs.  If you purchase mulch ask them how they store it to manage jumping worms. Try experimenting with a living much such as grasses or ground covers.  Don’t share plants from your garden with others or transport your soil. Clean your boots or shoes after you have been walking in your garden.  Remember that they are annual. They lay eggs in late summer so you cannot be transporting eggs earlier in the year.  Unfortunately, we will all have them eventually. I wish I could give you a more promising future.  https://extension.umn.edu/identify-invasive-species/jumping-worms#controlling-jumping-worms-1883163 https://arboretum.wisc.edu/news/arboretum-news/research-update-jumping-worms-and-sleeping-cocoons/

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Hi Deb -  Thanks for getting back to me, and for the additional information, very helpful.      I spoke with Laura Van Riper, DNR, at length this morning.  I have been added to the EDDMaps with photos, it's so disheartening.  I was happy to see the emotional support information yesterday on your website, that helped.      I'm planning on sharing info with my neighbors and friend groups.  I also plan to reach out to Vigoro and the Mulch and Soil Council, I've been using products they endorsed.       Laura talked about trying different strategies in different areas of the yard to see what works best.  Now that I'm getting a little beyond the freaking out phase,  , I can work on doing that.       Couple of questions:  I'm assuming my plants that are looking droopy, are being affected - some beautiful, big, established Coral Bells are being affected, along with some of the new plantings.  They're killing some Campanula - Blue Clips also, among other things.   Do people try taking off the top layer of the soil?   Regarding them being annual, and they lay eggs late summer, and not transporting, will you clarify that? The adult worms die, but leave the eggs to overwinter, then hatch in the spring?   Thanks, unclear on the "transporting."  Thanks!         I worry about our wooded back acre.  I understand they shouldn't affect old growth.  I guess it's good for buckthorn saplings, although they probably don't affect those invaders.      Thanks for the information and for all you do.  I'd be interested in any tasks that may help.     Take care. goal: Diagnose and treat the issues affecting multiple pine and hemlock trees, including sap weeping and needle blight.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I have multiple varieties of pines and many have ‘sores’ where sap is bubbling out and dripping. They were treated by an arborist on 7/17 for pitch mass boring insects with some sort of trunk wash. It still appears some spots are active and look like attached. I pulled a sticky bit off this spot before taking picture. The arborist assures me his treatment is working and this will dry up and harden. I’m not so sure. Thoughts?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Do you have an extensive infestation of your conifers that the arborist felt needed to be treated? Typically, pitch mass borer does not negatively effect the overall health of a pine tree. However, as with most things "it depends"--on overall health of the tree, if another disease moves in, etc.  It might be that your arborist applied treatment too late in the season. Here is a link to a question similar to yours from a couple years ago. " Pitch mass borers are more difficult to control, but injection of emamectin benzoate should provide protection for 2 - 3 years. There is generally only one larva in each pitch mass, so it is possible to dig through the mass and locate the larva, if there are only a few masses and the are within safe reach. It typically takes a tree 2 - 3 weeks to take up an insecticide administered by injection. Make sure there is adequate soil moisture to ensure uptake. You don't want the soil saturated, but it has to be moist for the tree to take up the product. There are several different pitch mass borers each with their own lifecycle. Because we don't know which one(s) you have, it is not possible to know whether it is too late to apply the insecticide. It is definitely too late to apply a preventative trunk spray, but the systemic insecticide will spread throughout the tree tissue that the larvae are feeding on, and kill any that are still actively feeding. It will also protect the tree for 2 - 3 years. Please note that pitch mass borers tend to attack trees that are already stressed. To best help your trees, take measures to reduce stress as possible. Consider applying 2-3 inches of mulch, such as pine needles or wood chips, under the tree starting several inches out from the trunk and extending to the drip line. Mulch will help conserve moisture during dry conditions and reduce temperature swings in the soil. If possible, irrigate deeply (1 inch of water) once per week during prolonged hot, dry conditions—but do not overwater, as this will also stress the tree. You might also consider applying a low rate of nitrogen fertilizer (1 lb N per 1,000 sq ft) under the tree canopy, or spread evenly around the drip line of the tree. Fertilizer should be watered in, or spread before rain is expected. You could consider getting a soil test, which would let you know the soil pH and whether there are any nutrients lacking: https://homesoiltest.msu.edu/" According to the University of Massachusetts Amherst "Pitch can be removed and the single larva within destroyed. Physical/mechanical management of this insect, if it can be safely done, is a great way to manage the pitch mass borer on individual specimen trees. The act of just pulling the caterpillar from its pitch mass will kill it." You might try this technique on any masses of pitch you can reach. If you can find active borers in the pitch, you know the treatment did not work. (It may be that the tree is still "bleeding" from the damage borers and needs time to close off the wounds.) I'm not sure if this video link will work for you, but it shows what the larva looks like and how easy it can be to find it (it's not always this easy--sometimes you need to poke around in the tree with something like a coat hanger wire).  It is suggested that pruning conifers during the warmer months attracts pitch mass borer moths to your trees, so make sure you only prune in dormant months.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Nancy, I am not a tree expert by any means, so I am going to re-assign your question to someone with more expertise. He is busy, but he should get back to you soon. Of note is that many of your conifers are not native to SE Michigan. They are stressed by the different climate and soils from where they evolved and it makes them more susceptible to diseases and pests. We are losing Colorado blue spruces across SE Michigan. As you drive, look at the trees in people's yards. You will see that spruces are on decline.  I suspect that your trees will decline and ultimately succumb to these disease pressures. It is up to you whether you want to keep treating them and get a few additional years out of them. I would suggest looking at planting replacement trees now, so that when these conifers come down, you have trees ready to take their place (I would not recommend replacing them with conifers, since they are not doing well now).

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Nancy, It sounds like your arborist is trying hard to find solutions. The list of chemicals applied includes two fungicides and one insecticide. Unfortunately, the insecticide, Imidacloprid, is not effective against the larval stages of moths, including Zimmerman pine moth and pitch mass borers. It is unlikely to have the desired effect. As noted previously, these insects do not generally harm the tree, though they may if numbers are large enough.  To my knowledge, tebuconazole is not labeled for needlecast and I am unclear why they applied it, unless there is something else they are trying to treat. Chlorothalonil is the appropriate product for needlecast, and should be applied when needles are half expanded, and again 3 - 4 weeks later when needles are fully expanded, for blue spruce. I did not check needle expansion for the dates listed, but I would guess the chlorothalonil timing was reasonable. The appropriate time to apply fertilizer is in the spring around the time the trees begin to resume growth. Organic fertilizers are applied in the fall, because they take several months to break down into a form plants can take up. Regular (inorganic) fertilizers like your 13-13-13 are readily available to plants as soon as they are watered in. Fall application results in loss of much of the fertilizer over the winter. Take care!

For  an accurate diagnosis a sample can be sent to the plant disease lab. Treatment is much more effective if one knows what the disease is. https://pdc.umn.edu/

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: I have attached 3photos.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: https://fertilawnmn.com/turf-diseases/#:~:text=Fusarium%20Blight%20is%20a%20turf,is%20summer%20to%20late%20summer. https://www.extension.purdue.edu/extmedia/bp/bp-116-w.pdf https://www.canr.msu.edu/ipm/diseases/necrotic-ring-spot?language_id=  https://stewartslawn.com/blog/how-to-identify-and-treat-necrotic-ring-spot/  https://extension.psu.edu/turfgrass-diseases-damping-off-diseases-causal-fungi-pythium-rhizoctonia-and-fusarium-spp  Thank you for the photos. I am not convinced it is necrotic ring spot because some key signs aren’t present. The bleaching is also puzzling and can be a sign of too much propiconazole. I will ask a turf expert what she thinks. I reply may take a week or two because this is a busy time.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank youSent from my iPad On Sep 16, 2024, at 4:33 PM, Ask Extension wrote:﻿

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: You are welcome.

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Thanks for referring this.  It is difficult to diagnose turfgrass diseases without a close up look at the blade -- the blade usually has telltale lesions from the pathogen.  That's all by way of introduction, not that the photos aren't of value.   I'm wondering if this is actually pythium, and I base that on the one picture that has the very dark coloration and areas where it seems the individual spots may have melded to a larger spot.  Does the black feel greasy to the touch?   Another pathogen exacerbated by the weather and not frequent around here, BUT, I think that could be what this is.   If it is, do not walk on this area when it is wet - or any of the spots.  This spreads very easily when you mow or walk across it.  Be very light-handed with your nitrogen fertilizer, you don't want to push growth like you might on other diseases.  And -- stop watering the area.  Make sure it drains well because this one likes moisture.  IF you need to water, do it only once a week in the mornings so it dries and drains.   You may also see white cottony fungus in the early mornings, but that also can indicate other diseases.  See if this clears it up for you -- there is no need to use chemicals unless this spreads rapidly across other areas of the lawn.  Please reply back to this message if you have questions OR if you want to send photos of close ups of individual blades from the areas where the green grass meets the black or dead-looking areas.   Thank you for your patience.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you for your continued effort.  The black spots are dry. And I believe are holes from squirrels which I have seen digging. Not certain what to look for but  Looking up close with a microscope I could not see anything odd. See closeup photo.  Also while most of dry grass feels anchored to ground I have been able to pull some up and the roots appear dry (second photo)

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hello Diana Before I send this along to our weed expert, to confirm ID, please attach one or two more pictures of the nimblewill plant itself.  Take a small section dug up, laid out on a plain background, and photograph it from 8 inches away or so.   Spread out the stems and leaves  so we can see how they are arranged on the stem. Include a seedhead if possible.  It helps to put a coin or something beside it to give a sense of scale.  I attached a similar picture of nimblewill as an example of what is needed. Also, if you do not yet have them, here are Purdue’s and MSU’s Turf weed entries for nimblewill.  https://www.canr.msu.edu/ipm/diseases/nimblewill?language_id= https://turf.purdue.edu/nimblewill/

goal: Expand the garden with Dahlias and Zinnias without them being damaged by deer.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text:
Good afternoon! 

I am in Gambier, Ohio. We have a major deer population here. I am hoping to expand my Dahlias and Zinnias into the front yard but I am worried I might waste much time and money due to the deer population. I turned to google to find out if Zinnias and Dahlias are tasty to deer and found very mixed results. 

I thought I'd reach out and see if you had any insight or opinions on this?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Hi Chelsea,  Whether tasty or not, virtually no plant is safe from a hungry deer.  I regret to advise that neither dahlias nor zinnias are particularly deer resistant.  Although some sources suggest that dahlias are somewhat deer resistant, PennState Extension notes, "Dahlias are surprisingly disease and pest resistant; however, they are browsed by deer."  https://extension.psu.edu/the-dirt-on-dahlias  Zinnias are considered more resistant than dahlias, with Rutgers New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station extensive rating of plants' deer resistance considers zinnias as "seldom severely damaged" vs. "occasionally severely damaged."  https://njaes.rutgers.edu/deer-resistant-plants/   Cornell Cooperative Extension also has a factsheet listing deer resistant plants:  https://warren.cce.cornell.edu/gardening-landscape/deer-resistant-plants.  I hope this helps.  Thank you for your question.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: Thank you so much for your advice! I will look into deer deterring methods before expanding my garden. Chelsea  On Fri, Sep 6, 2024 at 10:26 PM Ask Extension <<personal data hidden>> wrote:

known.concern: Major deer population
known.user's research: Mixed results on deer resistance of Dahlias and Zinnias

missing: Current deer deterrent methods in use, if any
Specific area or conditions of the front yard where planting is planned

expected_output: Are you currently using any deer deterrent methods in your garden, or do you have specific conditions in your front yard that might affect the choice of deterrents?
title: Deer, Dahlias, and Zinnias

goal: Identify the unusual structures on a juniper tree.

dialog_context.speaker: user
dialog_context.text: These were on a juniper tree near Steelhead Falls. What are they?

dialog_context.speaker: expert
dialog_context.text: Wow, what an interesting question!  I have to admit, I don't have a good response.  My first reaction was that this photo looks like burrs from various weeds, such as cockleburr or burdock, that maybe were dropped by birds while feeding upon the burrs for the little seeds within.  My second response was to research about junipers, and yes, there are female trees with the bluish-gray berries we are familiar with, and also male trees with a smallish brownish-yellow cone.  Along those lines, I also found photos of smallish cones on similar trees like cedars and arborvitaes (Thuja family) and also cypresses (Cupressaceae family).  But none of those cones completely resembled the ones you photographed.  That's the best I can come up with.  If you want additional help, let me know and I can forward your question to other Ask Extension experts in horticulture.    Cindy Brown, OSU Sherman County Extension, Moro OR

dialog_context.speaker: expert

My second response was to research about junipers, and yes, there are female trees with the bluish-gray berries we are familiar with, and also male trees with a smallish brownish-yellow cone.  Along those lines, I also found photos of smallish cones on similar trees like cedars and arborvitaes (Thuja family) and also cypresses (Cupressaceae family).  But none of those cones completely resembled the ones you photographed.  That's the best I can come up with.  If you want additional help, let me know and I can forward your question to other Ask Extension experts in horticulture.    Cindy Brown, OSU Sherman County Extension, Moro OR
